projects.name: Underwater Diorama

steps.instruction: Cut a 12x12 inch piece of white cardstock and a 12x12 inch piece of clear acetate.
steps.visual_description: A square piece of white cardstock and a square piece of clear acetate.

steps.instruction: Design and cut out various sea creatures and coral shapes from colored paper. Paint them as desired.
steps.visual_description: Various shapes of fish, anemones, and coral cut from colored paper, some with painted details.

steps.instruction: Assemble the diorama by layering the cut-out elements between the cardstock and acetate sheets. Use glue to secure the layers.
steps.visual_description: A layered arrangement of paper cutouts, resembling an underwater scene, sandwiched between cardstock and acetate.

steps.instruction: Use thread to suspend some elements within the diorama for a floating effect.
steps.visual_description: Some paper elements are attached with thin threads to create a sense of depth and movement.

tips: Use a variety of textures and colors for a more dynamic scene.
Consider adding small embellishments like glitter for a watery effect.
projects.finished_product_description: A three-dimensional diorama depicting an underwater scene with various sea creatures and coral, enclosed within a clear acetate and cardstock frame.

diagram_descriptions: A detailed, layered mixed-media diorama featuring several fish, including clownfish and a lionfish, along with coral and anemone elements, all enclosed within a white cardstock frame and clear acetate front. The background appears to be a light blue-green gradient. The elements are arranged to create a sense of depth, with some pieces appearing closer and others further back.
A white pop-up dove or butterfly structure is shown in the center of the page.

Image of a pop-up scene with a vanity table and a chair.

Two pop-up paper structures, one yellow and one red, are shown against a white background. The yellow structure appears to be a folded piece of paper with a geometric cut-out creating a 3D effect. The red structure is similar, also showing a folded paper design with a cut-out and a 3D pop-up element.

steps.instruction: Print the template onto white cardstock. Cut out all the pieces.
steps.visual_description: Template pieces for pop-up card

steps.instruction: Score and fold the card base along the indicated lines.
steps.visual_description: White cardstock folded into a card base

steps.instruction: Assemble the pop-up elements by gluing the printed paper pieces onto the cardstock cutouts.

steps.instruction: Add details using thread to create the appearance of water and movement.

tips: Use a fine-tip glue applicator for precise gluing.
Be careful when cutting intricate details with the craft knife.

projects.name: Sturdy Backing Sheet

steps.instruction: Cut the card (cardboard) in half, down the line of the gutter crease.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a ruler and a craft knife, cutting a black card in half on a cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Take one half of the card and run sticky tape along the back.
steps.visual_description: Hands applying sticky tape to the edge of a black card half.

steps.instruction: Cut the ends of the tape off at the top and bottom.
steps.visual_description: Hands using a craft knife to trim excess sticky tape from the top and bottom edges of a card.

steps.instruction: Take the other half of the card and place it on top, outside facing upwards, and fold the sticky tape over it.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding two halves of a card, aligning them, and folding tape over.

steps.instruction: The backing sheet is now complete.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a completed backing sheet, which is folded in half.

tips: For a pop-up in which the backing sheet opens flat (see Multi-piece Techniques, page 69), it is important that the sheet does open absolutely flat, so that the pop-up can assume its correct three-dimensional shape.
The crease down the middle of the backing sheet is referred to as the gutter crease.
A sheet of card that is scored or indented down the centre to create the gutter crease will not completely unfold to lie flat, so the crease must be made by other means.
projects.finished_product_description: A sturdy backing sheet for a pop-up.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a pop-up element attached to a backing sheet, with arrows indicating 'pop-up' and 'gutter crease'.

A pop-up paper craft with abstract geometric shapes in light blue, creating a layered, three-dimensional effect. The shapes appear to be folded and cut from a light blue textured paper, with some areas showing shadows and depth. There is a hint of text at the top edge of the page, partially obscured.

projects.name: Santa Pop-Up Card

steps.instruction: Fold the white cardstock in half lengthwise to create a center crease. Unfold.
steps.visual_description: A white sheet of paper folded in half lengthwise, then unfolded, showing a crease down the middle.

steps.instruction: On the folded edge, measure and mark 1 inch from the top and bottom edges. Draw a line connecting these marks to the center crease, forming a V-shape.
steps.visual_description: The folded paper with lines drawn from the top and bottom edges to the center crease, forming a V.

steps.instruction: Cut along the V-shaped lines from the folded edge to the center crease. These cuts will form the pop-up mechanism.
steps.visual_description: The paper with two cuts made from the folded edge towards the center crease.

steps.instruction: Gently push the cut sections inward to create the pop-up base. Fold the card along the original center crease.
steps.visual_description: The paper with the cut sections pushed inward, forming a 3D structure when the card is folded.

steps.instruction: Cut out Santa's hat from the red cardstock. The hat should be approximately 2 inches tall and 3 inches wide at the brim, with a curved top.
steps.visual_description: A red paper cutout shaped like Santa's hat.

steps.instruction: Cut out Santa's beard and face features (eyes, nose, mouth) from the white cardstock. These should be layered to create depth.
steps.visual_description: White paper cutouts for Santa's beard and facial features.

steps.instruction: Assemble Santa's face by gluing the beard and facial features onto the pop-up structure inside the card. Attach the red hat to the top.
steps.visual_description: The pop-up structure inside the card with Santa's face and hat assembled.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Glue beard and face features onto the pop-up mechanism. Attach hat to the top of the pop-up structure.

tips: Score folds lightly with a bone folder for cleaner creases.
projects.finished_product_description: A white pop-up greeting card featuring a 3D Santa Claus face with a red hat and white beard.

diagram_descriptions: A white pop-up card with a red Santa hat and a white beard and face structure emerging from the center fold. The card is open at a 90-degree angle, showing the 3D effect. The background is a soft, textured pinkish-beige.
A small graphic with a diamond shape inside a square, with diagonal lines within the diamond.

projects.name: Angle of Crease Pop-up Technique

steps.instruction: Fold a sheet of stiff paper in half. Measure along the folded edge (the gutter crease) and mark the halfway point. Using a pencil, draw a line from the crease into the middle of the paper. Cut along this line.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a folded orange sheet of paper, cutting a vertical slit with scissors from the folded edge towards the center.

steps.instruction: This is the critical step. Pull up the triangle while also folding the paper shut again. All the creases must form simultaneously â€“ they should appear as shown here. Note, there is only one mountain crease, down the middle of the triangle; the others are valleys.
steps.visual_description: Hands manipulating a folded orange sheet of paper, pulling up a central triangular pop-up element. The image clearly shows one mountain crease down the middle of the triangle and valley creases on either side.

details.position: from end of slit to opposite edge, forming a triangle

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: This diagram indicates the angle of crease and shape of slit formation for the step-by-step sequence. In the Angle of Crease technique, the shape of the slit remains constant but the angle of the crease changes, creating a range of surprisingly different forms. In some variations, the slit is at 45 degrees to the gutter crease.

tips: Only one mountain crease should form down the middle of the pop-up triangle; other creases are valleys.
projects.finished_product_description: A folded paper with a triangular pop-up element, demonstrating the Angle of Crease technique. This technique, derived from the elementary Single Slit, allows for an astonishing range of interesting forms by varying the crease angle.

diagram_descriptions: Photo of hands holding a folded orange sheet of paper, cutting a vertical slit with scissors from the folded edge towards the center.

Line diagram on a white background showing a folded paper. A red solid line indicates a slit originating from the folded edge, and another red solid line extends from the end of the slit to the opposite side, forming a triangular crease.

Photo of hands manipulating a folded orange sheet of paper, pulling up a central triangular pop-up element. The image clearly shows one mountain crease down the middle of the triangle and valley creases on either side.
Photo of a white pop-up sculpture of a bird with outstretched wings, emerging from a sculpted base, against a plain background.

projects.name: Single Slit

steps.instruction: Carefully fold along a line from the end of the slit to the gutter crease, creating a triangle. Press firmly.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding an orange paper triangle along a line from the slit to the gutter crease.

steps.instruction: Unfold the triangle so that it is in its previous position, then fold it to the back of the sheet, once again creasing firmly along the same line.
steps.visual_description: Hands unfolding and then refolding an orange paper triangle to the back along the same crease line.

steps.instruction: Unfold the triangle once again, then unfold the gutter crease, opening out the card completely.
steps.visual_description: Hands unfolding an orange paper triangle and then unfolding the gutter crease to open the card.

steps.instruction: Finally, close the pop-up and press it flat, strengthening all the creases.
steps.visual_description: Hands closing an orange pop-up card and pressing it flat.

tips: This configuration of mountain and valley creases in relation to the gutter crease and to the slit, will be seen many times throughout the book.
projects.finished_product_description: An orange pop-up card with a triangular opening created by a single slit and folds.

diagram_descriptions: A series of four images showing the process of creating a pop-up element in an orange card. The first image shows hands folding a triangle. The second shows the triangle unfolded and then folded to the back. The third shows the triangle unfolded again and the gutter crease being opened. The fourth image shows hands closing the pop-up card flat. A fifth, larger image shows the finished pop-up element, which is a triangular opening in an orange card.
A small graphic with a black diamond shape with a white border and hatched shading inside.

Top image shows two folded paper structures with angled creases and slits, against a blue sky background. The left structure is darker brown, the right is light tan. Text to the right describes these as variations I (left) and II (right), noting that different crease angles create different forms despite a constant slit shape.

Middle image shows three folded paper structures with angled creases and diamond-shaped cutouts, against an orange background. The structures are light blue. Text below describes these as variations III (left), IV (center), and V (right), noting that variation V with a near-horizontal crease pivots more when opened, while the other two remain static.

Bottom section shows five diagrams labeled I, II, III, IV, and V. Each diagram depicts a flat piece of paper with black lines indicating edges and folds, and red lines indicating creases. Diagram I shows a horizontal crease and a diagonal crease. Diagram II shows a horizontal crease and a vertical crease forming an L-shape. Diagram III shows a vertical crease and two diagonal creases forming a V-shape. Diagram IV shows a vertical crease and two diagonal creases forming an inverted V-shape. Diagram V shows a vertical crease and two diagonal creases forming a diamond shape. The text 'ONE-PIECE TECHNIQUES' is printed vertically along the left side of this section.

projects.name: FISH

materials.color: brown, orange, various shades of blue, light green

tips: The off-centre depiction of the fish adds much visual interest to the pop-up.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a fish with an animated double 'V' mouth, created using the Angle of Crease technique, which closes as the card opens. The background uses torn paper to create water effects. The finished pop-up fish has a height of 30 cm (12 in).

diagram_descriptions: A photograph of a finished pop-up card. The card is open, displaying a brown and orange patterned fish with a light green, open, double 'V' mouth. The fish is positioned off-centre against a background of torn blue paper strips, creating a water effect. The overall height of the pop-up is 30 cm (12 in).

projects.name: Shape of Slit

steps.instruction: Having drawn the construction, use a craft knife to cut along the brown lines.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a craft knife cutting along brown lines drawn on a piece of paper.

steps.instruction: Fold along the two green lines, one at the top and the other at the bottom, creating valley creases.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a piece of paper along two green lines, creating valley creases.

steps.instruction: Open the pop-up, and re-crease the gutter crease as a mountain fold.
steps.visual_description: Hands opening a pop-up structure and re-creasing a gutter crease into a mountain fold.

steps.instruction: Similarly, re-crease the small step-shaped pop-up at the bottom of the paper (on the left of the picture) to create a mountain crease down this part of the gutter.
steps.visual_description: Hands re-creasing a small step-shaped pop-up at the bottom of a paper structure to form a mountain crease.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Fold and crease the paper according to the diagram and instructions to create a pop-up structure.

tips: The arms of the pop-up pierce the plane of the backing sheet to create a structure that can be viewed from all sides.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up structure with interlocking slits, viewed from the side.

templates.name: Diagram for Slit Technique
templates.shape_description: A rectangle with a series of interlocking 'E' shaped cut lines drawn in brown and two green lines indicating fold positions.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a sheet of paper folded in half with a pattern of brown lines for cutting and green lines for folding.
A close-up of a hand using a craft knife to cut along drawn lines on paper.
A close-up of hands folding a piece of paper along green lines to create valley creases.
A close-up of hands opening a pop-up and re-creasing a gutter as a mountain fold.
A close-up of hands re-creasing a small step-shaped pop-up at the bottom of the paper into a mountain crease.
A large, detailed image of the finished pop-up structure, showing its three-dimensional form and interlocking slits, viewed from a low angle.

projects.name: Dove
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up dove design with a cloud base.

diagram_descriptions: A white paper pop-up dove with outstretched wings, standing on a white cloud-shaped base. The background is a light blue watercolor wash.

projects.name: Shape of Slit Variations

materials.dimensions: not specified, implied to be rectangular sheets

steps.instruction: Fold a piece of paper or cardstock in half.
steps.visual_description: Implied by the cutting diagrams showing a folded sheet.

steps.instruction: Using the provided diagrams (I-V) as a guide, cut slits into the folded paper along the red lines.
steps.visual_description: Five diagrams (I-V) showing red lines on folded paper, indicating cut patterns.

steps.instruction: Open the folded paper and gently push the cut sections to create a pop-up form. Experiment with different cuts and creases to understand the possibilities of one-piece pop-ups.
steps.visual_description: Photos of five different finished pop-up forms corresponding to the diagrams.

details.position: from bottom-left corner diagonally up to the center fold, then a quarter-circle arc from the center fold to the top edge
from bottom-left corner, a stepped line upwards, then a diagonal line from the top of the stepped line to the top-right corner of the folded edge
a wavy line starting from the bottom edge, curving upwards and then downwards, ending at the center fold
a P-shaped cut, starting from the bottom edge, going vertically up, then curving right and down, ending at the center fold
a vertical line from the bottom edge, then a short horizontal line to the right, then a diagonal line upwards to the center fold

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The red lines in the diagrams indicate the cuts to be made on a folded piece of paper. The resulting pop-up forms are shown in the photographs above.

tips: A little time spent making these, and any other variations that come to mind, will quickly create a firm understanding of the basic cutting and creasing possibilities of one-piece pop-ups.
projects.finished_product_description: A collection of five distinct one-piece pop-up forms, each created by different slit variations on a folded sheet of paper or cardstock. The forms include geometric shapes, curved elements, and stepped structures, demonstrating various three-dimensional effects achievable through simple cuts and creases.

diagram_descriptions: Top photo: Two white pop-up forms against a blue background. The left form (corresponding to diagram I) features a large arched opening with a diamond-shaped pop-up element in the center. The right form (corresponding to diagram II) shows a more angular, stepped pop-up structure with multiple vertical and diagonal folds.

Middle photo: Three brown/beige pop-up forms against a light background with a blue gradient. The left form (corresponding to diagram III) has two upward-curving wings. The center form (corresponding to diagram IV) features a central pop-up element with two rounded cut-outs on either side. The right form (corresponding to diagram V) displays an angular, L-shaped pop-up element extending from the base.
Bottom row of diagrams: Five small illustrations labeled I, II, III, IV, V, each showing a folded rectangular sheet of paper with red lines indicating the cutting patterns for each pop-up variation.

projects.name: PIRATE DUCKS

steps.instruction: Create a complex cut silhouette from a photocopied drawing.
steps.visual_description: A drawing of ships with ducks on them, designed to be cut out.

steps.instruction: Add artwork using colored pencil.
steps.visual_description: The drawing is enhanced with colored pencil details.

steps.instruction: Make the card from a simple pop-up technique - the Asymmetric Slit.
steps.visual_description: The card is folded to create a 3D scene.

steps.instruction: Give the card strength by folding it as a double layer.
steps.visual_description: The paper is folded to create a thicker, more stable card.

projects.finished_product_description: A whimsical pop-up card featuring a scene with pirate ducks on ships, a coastline with castles, and the sea. The card is made from a complex cut silhouette and added artwork, using a simple pop-up technique called the Asymmetric Slit. It is made from a photocopied drawing colored with pencil and strengthened by folding into a double layer.

diagram_descriptions: A photograph of a pop-up card titled 'PIRATE DUCKS'. The card depicts a nautical scene with several ships carrying ducks dressed as pirates. In the foreground, two ships are visible, one larger with a red flag and a brown hull, and a smaller one to its left. In the background, a coastline with castles is depicted. The sea is represented by wavy lines. The card is open, showing its 3D pop-up structure.

projects.name: Asymmetric Slit Variations

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: See description for details on construction and slit formation.

projects.finished_product_description: Three examples of pop-up cards with asymmetric slits. The first (left) shows a curved slit. The second (center) shows a variation where the gutter crease does not form the bottom part of the pop-up, requiring the entire construction to be drawn on an uncreased sheet. The third (right) shows a slit formed in line with the gutter.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram labeled 'I' showing a rectangle with a curved red line and a vertical green line down the center.
Diagram labeled 'II' showing a rectangle with a curved red line and a vertical green line down the center.
Diagram labeled 'III' showing a rectangle with two angled red lines and a vertical green line down the center.
A photograph showing three pop-up paper constructions with asymmetric slits, viewed from the front.

projects.name: Asymmetric Angles

steps.instruction: Having carefully drawn the construction, cut along the brown line.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a piece of white paper on a green cutting mat. One hand holds a ruler along a brown line, and the other hand uses a craft knife to cut along the brown line. Red and brown lines are drawn on the paper.

steps.instruction: Indent or score the crease lines. Do not crease them by eye, as this will not be sufficiently accurate.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a piece of white paper on a green cutting mat. A ruler is placed along a red line, and a stylus is used to indent or score the line. Other lines are also visible on the paper.

steps.instruction: Begin to form the pop-up by creasing the red lines as mountain folds and the green lines as valley folds.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a piece of white paper that is partially folded. Red lines are being creased as mountain folds, and green lines are visible as valley folds, forming a pop-up structure.

steps.instruction: It is often easier to strengthen the creases by working from the back.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a piece of white paper from the back, reinforcing creases. The paper is partially folded, showing the structure of the pop-up.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up structure with asymmetric angles creating a perspective effect.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a triangle within a rectangle, with a vertical line bisecting the rectangle and the triangle. A horizontal line extends from the vertical line to the right, creating two triangles of unequal size on either side of the vertical line.

Diagram showing the same triangle and rectangle as the first diagram. A protractor is shown measuring the angle between the vertical line and the left diagonal line of the triangle. Double hash marks indicate the measured angle.

Diagram showing a triangle within a rectangle. The vertical line bisects the rectangle and the triangle. The left diagonal line of the triangle is shown with double hash marks, indicating an angle. A red line is drawn on the inside of the right-hand diagonal line, marking an angle.

Diagram showing a triangle within a rectangle. The vertical line bisects the rectangle and the triangle. The central section of the vertical line is erased. Colored lines are used to indicate folding and cutting lines: green lines for valley folds, red lines for mountain folds.

projects.name: Vase of Flowers

steps.instruction: Flatten the pop-up and press it firmly to reinforce the creases.
steps.visual_description: A hand is shown flattening a folded piece of paper with a cut-out section, pressing down on a crease with a finger.

tips: Note that one triangular face of the pop-up is larger than the other, and that unlike previous techniques the mountain crease is not in line with the gutter crease.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a vase of flowers with a unique perspective created by asymmetric angles. The design uses black outlines, minimal yellow touches, and textured card to create a graphite-like effect.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up card with a vase of daisies. The flowers are outlined in black with yellow centers and cast shadows.
A close-up view of a pop-up mechanism being flattened by hand, showing a cut-out section and creases.
A partially assembled pop-up structure showing two angled panels, one with a beige insert, forming a V-shape.

projects.name: Asymmetric Angles Variations

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Creases are now asymmetric. Any form made using the Asymmetric Slit technique can be adapted to have asymmetrically placed creases as well.

projects.finished_product_description: Three examples of asymmetric pop-up designs made from a single slit. The first two are similar, with the third showing a variation in the angles of the creases.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram I shows a diamond shape with a horizontal line through the center, and two intersecting red lines forming a smaller diamond within. Green lines outline the shape.

Diagram II shows a fan-like shape with a horizontal line through the center. A red line runs through the center of the fan, and a curved red line forms the outer edge of the fan. Green lines outline the shape.

Diagram III shows a shape with a horizontal line through the center. A red line extends from the left, forming an angle. A curved red shape is attached to the end of the red line. Green lines outline the shape.

projects.name: Single Slit Pop-up (Generations Technique)

steps.instruction: Fold a sheet of stiff paper in half. Using a pencil, measure and mark the halfway point along the gutter crease, then draw a line from the gutter crease to the centre of the folded paper and cut it (see fig 1).
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a folded white sheet of paper, cutting a short horizontal line from the fold with blue-handled scissors. Figure 1 shows a diagram of the folded paper with the cut line.

steps.instruction: Fold the lower half of the sheet so that the gutter crease and the edges meet exactly. Press firmly. Unfold this half of the paper, then open it out.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding the lower half of a white sheet of paper, aligning the gutter crease and edges precisely.

steps.instruction: Create the pop-up by pulling up the lower half of the card and forming a mountain crease. At the same time, close the paper shut again â€“ all the creases must be created simultaneously.
steps.visual_description: Hands opening a folded white sheet of paper, revealing a 3D pop-up structure resembling a cube emerging from the center.

steps.instruction: Draw a second line from halfway down the pop-up to halfway across to the right-hand edge. Cut along this line, making sure you cut through all four layers of paper (see fig 2).
dimensions_mentioned: halfway across to the right-hand edge
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a folded white sheet of paper with a previous cut, cutting an L-shaped line into it with blue-handled scissors, ensuring all four layers are cut. Figure 2 shows a diagram of the folded paper with the L-shaped cut line.

steps.instruction: Crease as before (see step 2), then unfold and open the sheet.
steps.visual_description: Hands creasing the newly cut section of the folded white paper, similar to the action in step 2. Figure 3 shows a diagram of the folded paper after the L-shaped cut, with multiple layers visible.

projects.finished_product_description: A sheet of paper with a single pop-up structure created by a series of cuts and folds, forming new creases that can be used to generate more pop-ups in successive 'generations', leading to complex forms.

templates.shape_description: A folded rectangular sheet of paper with a horizontal cut line. The line starts from the central fold (gutter crease) and extends towards the center of the folded paper. The ends of the cut line are marked with small vertical dashes.

templates.name: Second Pop-up Cut (Fig 2)
templates.shape_description: A folded sheet of paper, already having the initial horizontal cut. An L-shaped cut line is drawn on it. This line starts from the end of the previous cut, goes vertically downwards, then turns horizontally to the right-hand edge of the paper. The ends of the L-shaped cut are marked with small vertical dashes.

templates.name: Result of Second Cut (Fig 3)
templates.shape_description: A folded sheet of paper showing the result of the L-shaped cut, with the cut-out section removed. Multiple layers of the folded paper are visible, indicating the depth of the cut. Small vertical lines mark the end of the cut.

diagram_descriptions: Photo showing hands holding a folded white sheet of paper, cutting a short horizontal line from the fold with blue-handled scissors.
Photo showing hands folding the lower half of a white sheet of paper, aligning the gutter crease and edges precisely.

projects.name: Pop-up Steps

steps.instruction: Form the mountain and valley creases as before (see step 3), to create another two pop-up shapes.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a piece of paper folded to create a stepped pop-up shape with three steps.

steps.instruction: As before, make a third cut from halfway down the new pop-up to halfway across to the right-hand edge. Crease as before (see steps 2 and 3), this time to create four smaller pop-ups.
steps.visual_description: Hands using scissors to cut a piece of paper that is part of a pop-up structure. The cut is made from the middle of a new pop-up section towards the right edge.

tips: The pop-up could have more generations than the three shown here, each time doubling the number of pop-ups made.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up structure resembling steps or a staircase, with multiple tiers of increasing height.

diagram_descriptions: A large diagram showing a pop-up structure with multiple steps, viewed from the front.

projects.name: Double Slit Pop-up (Angles of Creases)

steps.instruction: Fold a sheet of stiff paper in half. Draw two horizontal lines from the gutter crease to the centre of the paper, then join them. Cut along the two horizontal lines. (For clarity, coloured lines have been used in this example, but you should draw in pencil.)
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a green sheet of paper folded in half, using scissors to cut two parallel horizontal lines from the folded edge towards the center of the paper, creating a rectangular flap.

steps.instruction: Carefully make a crease between the two slits, folding the paper forwards.
steps.visual_description: Hands pressing down on the rectangular flap created in step 1, folding it forwards to create a horizontal crease between the two slits.

steps.instruction: Then fold the flap backwards along the same crease line.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding the rectangular flap backwards along the same crease line, reversing the fold from step 2.

steps.instruction: Unfold the flap back to its previous position, then open out the card.
steps.visual_description: Hands unfolding the flap back to its flat position, then opening the entire green card. The cut section is now visible as a rectangular opening in the center of the card.

steps.instruction: To form the pop-up, pull up the central section of the gutter crease to create a mountain. All the other creases remain as valleys. Close the pop-up shut and press it flat to strengthen all the creases.
steps.visual_description: Hands manipulating the central section of the card, pulling up the cut rectangle to form a three-dimensional box-like pop-up structure when the card is opened.

details.position: two horizontal lines from gutter crease to center, joined

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The pop-up is formed by pulling the central section of the gutter crease to create a mountain fold, while other creases remain as valley folds.

tips: For clarity, coloured lines have been used in this example, but you should draw in pencil.
projects.finished_product_description: A green card opened to reveal a rectangular box pop-up structure. Another example shows a stylized face pop-up with hair and glasses, made from light brown paper, demonstrating a more complex Double Slit design.

diagram_descriptions: Top right image: Hands holding a green sheet of paper folded in half, using scissors to cut two parallel horizontal lines from the folded edge towards the center, creating a rectangular flap.
Middle left image: Hands pressing down on the rectangular flap, folding it forwards to create a horizontal crease between the two slits.
Middle right image: Hands folding the rectangular flap backwards along the same crease line, reversing the fold from the previous step.
Bottom left (top) image: Hands unfolding the flap back to its flat position, then opening the entire green card. The cut section is now visible as a rectangular opening.
Bottom left (bottom) image: Hands manipulating the central section of the card, pulling up the cut rectangle to form a three-dimensional box-like pop-up structure.

projects.name: Shapes of Slits

steps.instruction: Having carefully drawn the construction, cut along the brown lines.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a piece of cardstock and cutting along red lines with blue scissors.

steps.instruction: To form the pop-up, make two creases, folding the paper forwards and backwards along the red lines.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a piece of cardstock along creases.

steps.instruction: Open out the card and form the first simple step-shaped pop-up by pulling the step-shape upwards to create a mountain crease.
steps.visual_description: Hands opening a card and pulling a step-shaped section upwards.

steps.instruction: Then create the other, more complex pop-up by reinforcing the creases and closing the card simultaneously.
steps.visual_description: Hands reinforcing creases and closing a card with a complex pop-up structure.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Draw construction, cut along brown lines, fold along red lines to create pop-up shapes.

tips: The slits need not always run into the gutter crease.

details.description: Two zig-zag lines. One starts from the top-left, goes down-right, then up-right. The other starts from the top-right, goes down-left, then up-left. These form two 'V' shapes, one inverted, across the center.

projects.name: Asymmetric Mountain

steps.instruction: Using a pencil, draw a crease down the centre of a stiff piece of paper. Draw two horizontal lines that extend further to the right of the vertical line than to the left. Connect the horizontals with vertical lines, to form a rectangle.
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows a rectangular piece of paper with a central vertical line. An inner rectangle is drawn, with its left vertical line aligned with the center line. The top and bottom horizontal lines of this inner rectangle extend further to the right of the center vertical line than to the left.

steps.instruction: Measure the distance between the centre line and the vertical line to its left. Reproduce that distance, measuring it from the inside of the right-hand vertical. Draw another vertical line at this point.
dimensions_mentioned: distance between the centre line and the vertical line to its left
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows the previous drawing with measurement marks. The distance between the center line and the inner left vertical line is indicated. A new vertical line is drawn inside the inner rectangle on the right, at a distance from the inner right vertical line equal to the measured distance.

steps.instruction: Erase the central section of the gutter crease. (For clarity, coloured lines have been used here to show which creases are for folding and which are for cutting.)
steps.visual_description: Diagram shows the final construction lines. The central vertical line is erased within the inner rectangle. Green lines indicate fold lines, and brown lines indicate cut lines.

steps.instruction: Having drawn the construction, cut along the brown lines using a craft knife.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a pair of hands cutting along the brown lines of the drawn construction on a piece of paper using a red craft knife on a green cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Using an indenting tool and a ruler, indent all the creases, then begin to form the creases individually.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a pair of hands using an indenting tool and a ruler to indent the creases on the paper. The paper is partially folded, showing the central pop-up section.

steps.instruction: It is often easier to reinforce the creases from behind.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a pair of hands reinforcing the creases of the pop-up structure from behind, revealing the 'asymmetric mountain' shape.

tips: Remember to draw the complete construction before making any creases or cuts.
It is often easier to reinforce the creases from behind.

projects.name: Asymmetric Mountain Variations

steps.instruction: Prepare a piece of cardstock for the pop-up base.
steps.visual_description: Blank cardstock

steps.instruction: Transfer the desired variation pattern (I, II, III, or IV) onto the cardstock, marking the green lines as fold lines and the red lines as cut lines.
steps.visual_description: Cardstock with pattern lines drawn

steps.instruction: Carefully cut along all marked red lines using a craft knife.
steps.visual_description: Cardstock with cut lines

steps.instruction: Score and fold along all marked green lines.
steps.visual_description: Cardstock with scored and folded lines

steps.instruction: Gently push the cut and folded sections to create the desired pop-up form, ensuring the slits are pushed up or down as per the variation's design.
steps.visual_description: Finished 3D pop-up form

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The pop-up forms are created by cutting along the red lines and folding along the green lines shown in the patterns, then pushing the cut sections to create the three-dimensional shape. The slits along the shorter step are pushed up along the longer step (Variation I), or slits change direction at the mountain crease (Variation II). Asymmetric mountains can be transformed into valleys where cut-away forms entwine (Variation III), or pop-up forms can be made to pierce the plane of the backing sheet (Variation IV).

tips: Pop-up forms can be made to pierce the plane of the backing sheet using one-piece techniques.
projects.finished_product_description: A series of pop-up card variations demonstrating different asymmetric mountain and valley forms, including free-standing shapes, entwined forms, and designs that pierce the backing sheet, all created using double slit techniques.

A red outline forms a shape with two upper arches and a central rectangular protrusion at the bottom, centered on the fold line, with two vertical slits (marked 'I') extending from the fold line to the top and bottom of the shape.

steps.instruction: Using an indenting tool and a ruler, indent all the crease lines.

Diagram showing the V-shape with the second horizontal line drawn in red, and other lines in green, indicating creasing and cutting lines.

projects.name: House

steps.instruction: Finally, close the pop-up, forming all of the creases simultaneously. Flatten the pop-up and press the creases to reinforce them.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a piece of paper with pre-cut slits and creases into a pop-up structure.

tips: The asymmetrical design gives a foreshortening effect.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a house with a chimney, windows, a door, and a tree, created using the Cut Away technique and colored pencils for surface decoration.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up card showing a house with a red roof and brown walls, two windows, a door, a chimney, and a green tree. The house is set against a background with a road leading to it.
A close-up view of a piece of white cardstock being folded by hands, showing pre-cut slits and creases that will form a pop-up element.
A pop-up structure with two angled planes, one yellow and one beige, creating a sense of depth and perspective.

projects.name: Asymmetric Angles Variation I

steps.instruction: The change of angle of the pop-up form at the mountain crease exaggerates the sense of distorted perspective that is common to most Asymmetric Angle pop-ups. The curious angles that result from this technique transform a pop-up that would be uninteresting if all the creases were parallel, into one with character.
steps.visual_description: A beige pop-up card with a simple house-like structure popping up from the center.

details.shape_description: An angled 'L' or 'V' shape, forming the outer perimeter of the pop-up.
Inner lines forming the angle of the 'L' shape.
A line extending from the corner of the 'L' to the central horizontal fold.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The diagram shows the cut and fold lines for the pop-up mechanism.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a simple, angled house-like structure that appears to have a distorted perspective due to asymmetric creasing.

projects.name: Asymmetric Angles Variation II

steps.instruction: The curious angles that result from this technique are shown to good effect, transforming a pop-up that would be uninteresting if all the creases were parallel, into one with character.
steps.visual_description: A blue pop-up card with an abstract 'E' or 'F' shape popping up from the center.

details.shape_description: An abstract 'E' or 'F' like shape, forming the outer perimeter of the pop-up.
Inner lines forming the main structure of the 'E' shape.
Several lines connecting parts of the 'E' shape to the central horizontal fold.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The diagram shows the cut and fold lines for the pop-up mechanism.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring an abstract, angled 'E' or 'F' shape, demonstrating how asymmetric angles add character to the design.

projects.name: Asymmetric Angles Variation III

steps.instruction: This bizarre pop-up is not made inside the asymmetric creases but outside. Note how the mountain crease on the ring is in line with the mountain crease inside the conventional asymmetric configuration of creases.
steps.visual_description: A grey pop-up card with a circular or ring-like shape popping up, featuring a central 'V' or heart-like cut-out.

details.shape_description: A circular or ring-like shape, forming the outer perimeter of the pop-up, with a central 'V' or heart-like cut-out.
Inner lines forming the structure of the ring and the central 'V' shape.
Lines connecting parts of the ring and 'V' shape to the central horizontal fold.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The diagram shows the cut and fold lines for the pop-up mechanism, where the pop-up is formed outside the main asymmetric creases.

projects.finished_product_description: A unique pop-up card featuring a ring shape with a central 'V' cut-out, where the pop-up is formed by creases outside the conventional asymmetric configuration.

projects.name: Asymmetric Angles Variation IV

steps.instruction: For fun, the creases and slits are 'textured' with the addition of small Cut Away shapes.
steps.visual_description: A beige pop-up card with a triangular shape featuring scalloped or serrated edges, popping up from the center.

details.shape_description: A triangular shape with scalloped/serrated edges, forming the outer perimeter of the pop-up.
Inner lines forming the structure of the triangular pop-up.
Lines connecting parts of the triangle to the central horizontal fold.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The diagram shows the cut and fold lines for the pop-up mechanism, incorporating small cut-away shapes for texture.

projects.finished_product_description: A playful pop-up card featuring a triangular shape with textured, scalloped edges, achieved by adding small cut-away shapes to the creases and slits.

diagram_descriptions: Top image: Two pop-up cards. The left card is beige and features a simple, angled house-like structure popping up. The right card is blue and displays an abstract 'E' or 'F' shape pop-up.

Middle image: Two pop-up cards. The left card is grey and shows a circular/ring-like pop-up with a central 'V' or heart-like cut-out. The right card is beige and presents a triangular pop-up with scalloped/serrated edges.

Bottom row: Four blueprint diagrams (labeled I, II, III, IV) on a light background. Each diagram shows a rectangular card with a central horizontal green valley fold line. Brown lines indicate cuts, red lines indicate mountain folds, and green lines indicate valley folds for the respective pop-up variations.

projects.name: Generations

steps.instruction: Fold a sheet of stiff paper in half. Draw two horizontal lines from the gutter crease and join them. Cut along the horizontal lines.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a sheet of paper folded in half, with a red rectangle drawn on it, and a craft knife cutting along the top line of the rectangle.

steps.instruction: Make a crease between the ends of the slits, folding the paper forwards then backwards along the same line.
steps.visual_description: A piece of paper with two parallel slits cut into it, being folded in the middle between the slits.

steps.instruction: Open the sheet of paper. Create a conventional pop-up by pulling the step shape up while closing the card - all the creases must form simultaneously. The pop-up will have one mountain crease, and the rest are valleys.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a piece of paper that has been folded and cut, showing a step-like pop-up structure forming as the card is closed.

steps.instruction: Close the pop-up again and repeat step 1. You should cut through all four layers of paper, ending halfway across the remainder of the sheet.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a piece of paper with scissors cutting a slit, following the pattern of a previous cut.

steps.instruction: Repeat step 2 and crease between the ends of the slits. Open the paper out once again.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a piece of paper with two parallel slits, folding it between the ends of the slits.

steps.instruction: Create two new smaller pop-ups, using the same method as in step 3.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a piece of paper that has been folded and cut, showing a pop-up structure with multiple steps.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Follow steps to create pop-up structure.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card with multiple steps or layers.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a rectangle with two horizontal red lines near the top and bottom edges, labeled 'fig 1'.
Diagram showing a U-shaped piece with vertical cuts on the open ends and horizontal cuts near the top and bottom, with dashed lines indicating folds, labeled 'fig 2'.

projects.name: Generations Pop-up Steps

steps.instruction: Repeat the procedure, this time to make four new pop-ups (see fig 3).
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a folded white paper, with blue-handled scissors cutting along a marked line to create a pop-up shape with four steps.

steps.instruction: And repeat again, this time to make eight new pop-ups (see fig 4).
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a folded white paper, with blue-handled scissors cutting along a marked line to create a pop-up shape with eight steps.

pieces.name: four-step pop-up
pieces.shape: folded paper with four rectangular steps

pieces.name: eight-step pop-up
pieces.shape: folded paper with eight rectangular steps

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Each new generation doubles the number of steps.

tips: The four generations made here could be extended to five, six or even more, with each new generation doubling the number of steps, given a large enough sheet of paper.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card with multiple tiers of rectangular steps, demonstrating the Generations technique, shown against a red background.

projects.name: BRIDGE OF SIGHS
tips: Note how the gondolier in the right foreground gives a sense of scale to the bridge.
projects.finished_product_description: A sophisticated pop-up bridge structure, utilizing the Generations technique and Cut Away technique, creating a convincing sculptural effect. The bridge features arches, two sets of stairs, and a small building on top. A small cut-out figure of a gondolier is visible in the right foreground. The finished piece has a height of 11cm (4Â¼ in).

diagram_descriptions: Diagram fig 3: A top-down view of a folded paper piece, showing the internal cut lines for creating four rectangular pop-up steps of decreasing size. The cuts are marked with short horizontal lines.

Diagram fig 4: A top-down view of a folded paper piece, showing the internal cut lines for creating eight rectangular pop-up steps of decreasing size. The cuts are more intricate than fig 3, marked with short horizontal lines.
Photo showing hands holding a folded white paper, with blue-handled scissors cutting along a marked line to form the first set of pop-up steps (corresponding to step 7).
Photo showing hands holding a folded white paper, with blue-handled scissors cutting along a marked line to form a more complex set of pop-up steps (corresponding to step 8).
Photo of a finished pop-up project, a white paper structure with multiple tiers of rectangular steps, set against a plain red background.

Photo of the finished 'BRIDGE OF SIGHS' pop-up project, a white paper sculpture depicting a bridge with arches, two sets of stairs, and a small building on top. A small cut-out figure of a gondolier is visible in the right foreground, providing a sense of scale. The background is a light, plain color.
Diagram I shows a flat pattern with red and green lines indicating cuts and mountain folds. It features a curved shape and a smaller angular shape.

Diagram II shows a flat pattern with red and green lines. It depicts a symmetrical shape resembling an hourglass or a stylized 'A' with two rectangular cutouts labeled 'IC' and two larger rectangular cutouts labeled 'IB'. Measurements 'A' and 'B' are indicated.
Diagram III shows a flat pattern with red and green lines, depicting a symmetrical shape with two rectangular cutouts.
Diagram IV shows a flat pattern with red and green lines, featuring several angular and curved shapes arranged in a layered manner.
Diagram V shows a flat pattern with red and green lines, depicting a series of stacked rectangular shapes of decreasing width, with vertical lines indicating measurements.

Photograph of three pop-up paper sculptures. The left sculpture shows a spiral effect with a small element pushed in. The center sculpture shows multiple steps or platforms. The right sculpture shows a series of ascending steps.

Photograph of three pop-up paper sculptures. The left sculpture shows a spiral effect with a small element pushed in. The center sculpture shows multiple steps or platforms. The right sculpture shows a series of ascending steps.

projects.name: Cut Away

steps.instruction: Having carefully drawn the construction, cut along the brown lines. Note that there are two long cuts as well as the semicircle, square and triangle.
steps.visual_description: A piece of paper with a cut-out design, being cut with a craft knife. The design has a central 'W' shape with a semicircle above and a square and triangle below.

steps.instruction: Using an indenting tool and a ruler, indent all the creases.
steps.visual_description: A piece of paper with a design drawn on it, being scored with an indenting tool and ruler along pre-drawn lines.

steps.instruction: Form all the creases individually. You may find it easier to create some of the creases from the back.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a piece of paper with cut and scored lines to form a 3D shape.

steps.instruction: Finally, forming all the creases simultaneously, flatten the pop-up. Press the creases to reinforce them.
steps.visual_description: Hands flattening a partially formed pop-up structure.

projects.finished_product_description: A three-dimensional pop-up structure created from a single piece of paper, with a central 'W' shape and a circular opening.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a horizontal line across a rectangle, with two vertical lines equidistant from the center.
Diagram showing a rectangle with a horizontal line, and three shapes (semicircle, square, triangle) drawn on the vertical lines.
Diagram showing the previous design with colored lines indicating cuts (red and green) and folds (green).

A large photograph of a finished 'Cut Away' pop-up structure rising from a flat surface against a blue sky background. The structure is a stylized 'W' shape with a circular hole in the background element.

projects.name: Cut Aways (Dovetail-joint effect)

steps.instruction: Place Cut Aways along a single crease to create an overlapping dovetail-joint effect. Observe which creases form mountains and which form valleys.
steps.visual_description: Diagram I shows a rectangular piece with a central vertical line and three interlocking S-shaped cuts. Red lines indicate mountain folds, green lines indicate valley folds.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Fold along the central crease, ensuring the cut-away elements overlap to create the dovetail-joint effect.

tips: Note which creases are mountains and which are valleys for correct folding.
projects.finished_product_description: A folded piece of light brown paper with three interlocking, overlapping cut-away shapes creating a curious dovetail-joint effect.

projects.name: Cut Aways (Hearth and Fireplace Pop-up)

steps.instruction: Introduce Cut Aways into basic asymmetrical block forms (hearth and fireplace) to animate the geometric composition. Transform the geometric pop-up into a representational one.
steps.visual_description: Diagram II shows a rectangular piece with cuts and folds forming a hearth/fireplace structure with an arched opening and a mantelpiece. Red lines indicate mountain folds, green lines indicate valley folds. Labels 'A' and 'B' are present.

details.description: Forms a hearth and fireplace structure with an arched opening and a mantelpiece

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Follow the red (mountain) and green (valley) fold lines to construct the pop-up hearth and fireplace.

tips: The transformation of a geometric pop-up into one that is representational is often simpler than you might at first imagine.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card made from dark pink/brown paper, depicting a hearth and fireplace with an arched opening and a small object in front.

projects.name: Cut Aways (Chair with Cushion Pop-up)

steps.instruction: Transform two generations of conventional blocks into a chair with a cushion using Cut Aways. Pay attention to the Cut Aways at the top of the chair back, at the top and bottom of the cushion, and between the front legs.
steps.visual_description: Diagram III shows a rectangular piece with cuts and folds forming a chair structure with a rounded back, a cushion, and legs. Red lines indicate mountain folds, green lines indicate valley folds. Labels 'A' and 'B' are present.

details.description: Forms a chair structure with a rounded back, a cushion, and legs

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Follow the red (mountain) and green (valley) fold lines to construct the pop-up chair with a cushion.

tips: Note the specific locations of Cut Aways for the chair back, cushion, and legs.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card made from light pink/brown paper, depicting a chair with a rounded back, a cushion, and legs.

projects.name: Doves (Cut Away Repeat Pattern)

steps.instruction: Create a semi-abstract repeat design using the Cut Away technique to form negative/positive silhouettes of doves. Use more than one crease to extend the pattern sideways and establish the repeat.
steps.technique: paper cutting, pop-up construction, repeat pattern design
steps.visual_description: Photo of a multi-creased pop-up structure made from white paper, featuring a repeating pattern of cut-away doves, creating a sense of negative and positive space.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The pattern can be extended sideways by using multiple creases to establish the repeat.

tips: This design makes full use of the Cut Away technique to create a sense of negative/positive silhouettes.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up structure made from white paper, approximately 30 cm (12 in) high, featuring a repeating pattern of intricate cut-away doves, creating negative and positive silhouettes.

templates.name: Cut Away Dovetail Pattern
templates.shape_description: Rectangular base with a central vertical line. The cut consists of three interlocking S-shapes along this line. Red lines indicate mountain folds, green lines indicate valley folds.

templates.name: Cut Away Hearth and Fireplace Pop-up Pattern
templates.shape_description: Rectangular base with internal cuts and folds forming a hearth and fireplace structure, including an arched opening and a mantelpiece. Red lines indicate mountain folds, green lines indicate valley folds. Labels 'A' and 'B' are marked on the diagram.

templates.name: Cut Away Chair with Cushion Pop-up Pattern
templates.shape_description: Rectangular base with internal cuts and folds forming a chair structure, including a rounded back, a cushion, and legs. Red lines indicate mountain folds, green lines indicate valley folds. Labels 'A' and 'B' are marked on the diagram.

diagram_descriptions: Photo labeled 'I' showing a light brown folded paper pop-up with three interlocking, overlapping cut-away shapes along a central crease, creating a dovetail-joint effect. The background is a light blue-green gradient.

Photo labeled 'II (LEFT)' showing a dark pink/brown paper pop-up structure depicting a hearth and fireplace with an arched opening and a small object (possibly a log) in front. The background is a light blue-green gradient.
Photo labeled 'III (RIGHT)' showing a light pink/brown paper pop-up structure depicting a chair with a rounded back, a cushion, and legs. The background is a light blue-green gradient.

Line drawing labeled 'I' showing the flat pattern for the dovetail-joint effect. It is a rectangle with a central vertical line. The cut is a series of three interlocking S-shapes. Red lines indicate mountain folds, and green lines indicate valley folds.

Line drawing labeled 'II' showing the flat pattern for the hearth/fireplace pop-up. It is a rectangle with various internal cuts and folds forming the structure. Red lines indicate mountain folds, green lines indicate valley folds. Labels 'A' and 'B' are present at various points.

Line drawing labeled 'III' showing the flat pattern for the chair pop-up. It is a rectangle with various internal cuts and folds forming the structure. Red lines indicate mountain folds, green lines indicate valley folds. Labels 'A' and 'B' are present at various points.

Large photo at the bottom right showing a multi-creased pop-up structure made from white paper, featuring a repeating pattern of intricate cut-away doves. The pattern extends sideways, creating a sense of negative and positive silhouettes. The background is a light blue and white marbled pattern.

projects.name: Multi Slit

steps.instruction: Fold a stiff piece of paper in half. Using a pencil, carefully draw, then cut, a series of parallel lines, creating a step effect. Note that the two longest lines are the same length.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a yellow folded paper with pencil-drawn parallel lines of varying lengths on one half, and scissors cutting along these lines.

steps.instruction: Begin the creasing by folding back each step one at a time.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding back the cut strips on the yellow paper, showing the beginning of the pop-up effect.

steps.instruction: Make sure that all the strips lie neatly side by side.
steps.visual_description: Hands pressing down the folded strips on the yellow paper, ensuring they are neatly aligned.

steps.instruction: Fold all the steps backwards in the same way, then open the paper.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding the yellow paper, which has been folded and opened, showing the pop-up steps created by the slits.

steps.instruction: Create a series of conventional pop-ups, one below the other, by carefully lifting and creasing the steps one at a time.
steps.visual_description: Hands manipulating the yellow paper, lifting and creasing the pop-up steps to form a more defined structure.

steps.instruction: Close the pop-up and press it firmly to reinforce all the creases.
steps.visual_description: Hands closing the yellow pop-up structure, pressing it flat to reinforce the creases.

details.pattern: series of parallel lines of varying lengths, creating a step effect on one half of the folded paper

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Fold paper in half, cut parallel lines to create steps, fold back strips to form pop-up, reinforce creases.

tips: After Single and Double Slit techniques, the obvious extension is to use Multi Slits. The technique is ideal for creating beautiful rhythmic abstracts, but much of their success depends on accurate measurements, so take time to draw them up and construct them with care!

The techniques that follow do not readily fit into the mainstream one-piece techniques described, yet they form an important part of the vocabulary. As you will have observed, no technique is entirely distinct from all others so you will find in this section that many overlap with earlier techniques. Indeed, it is curious how one technique mutates into another, particularly when Generations and Cut Aways are used.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card with a multi-slit structure, demonstrating a step effect that can be used for rhythmic abstract designs or more complex pop-ups, such as the example of a card with a crocodile and wolf head.

diagram_descriptions: Image of a finished pop-up card with a brown frame, showing a green crocodile head on the left and a brown wolf head on the right, both appearing to pop out from the card.
Image 1: Hands holding a yellow folded paper with pencil-drawn parallel lines of varying lengths on one half, and scissors cutting along these lines.
Image 2: Hands folding back the cut strips on the yellow paper, showing the beginning of the pop-up effect.
Image 3: Hands pressing down the folded strips on the yellow paper, ensuring they are neatly aligned.
Image 4: Hands holding the yellow paper, which has been folded and opened, showing the pop-up steps created by the slits.
Image 5: Hands manipulating the yellow paper, lifting and creasing the pop-up steps to form a more defined structure.
Image 6: Hands closing the yellow pop-up structure, pressing it flat to reinforce the creases.

projects.name: Rectangular Pop-up Stairs

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Multiple parallel slits are cut into a folded base card, and the resulting strips are pushed forward to create a three-dimensional ascending staircase effect.

tips: The narrower the strips, the better the pop-up looks, though if they are too narrow, they become weak and the pop-up looks deflated instead of pert.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up structure resembling a staircase or a series of ascending rectangular blocks, made from yellow/orange paper, set against a reddish background.

projects.name: TIERED ABSTRACT

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Numerous slits are cut into a base card to create a series of concentric, tiered semicircular pop-up elements. The structure's complexity is based on the precise length of each slit and the width of the paper left between them.

projects.finished_product_description: A white pop-up structure creating the illusion of a number of tiered semicircles, resembling a multi-layered cake or monument, against a blue and white background. The structure is formed by many slits.

diagram_descriptions: Top image shows a pop-up card with a series of ascending rectangular blocks, resembling stairs, made from yellow-orange paper. The pop-up elements cast shadows on the base. The background is a gradient of orange to red.

Bottom image shows a white pop-up card featuring a complex tiered structure composed of numerous vertical strips arranged in concentric semicircles, creating a multi-layered, abstract form. The background is a light blue watercolor wash.

projects.name: Multi Slit Variation I: Asymmetric Mountain Crease

steps.instruction: Create multiple vertical slits in a sheet of cardstock. Form an Asymmetric Mountain crease on each strip, determining its placement by measuring its position in relation to the gutter crease. This will result in a pleasing twisted form.
steps.visual_description: Photo of an orange pop-up card with vertical strips folded into an asymmetric, twisted staircase-like structure.

details.pattern: series of vertical slits forming a V-shape

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Cut along the red lines. Crease the strips to form asymmetric mountain folds.

projects.finished_product_description: An orange pop-up card featuring a series of vertical strips, each with an asymmetric mountain crease, creating a twisted, staircase-like effect.

projects.name: Multi Slit Variation II: Alternate Lifted Strips

steps.instruction: Cut a series of horizontal slits into a sheet of cardstock. Lift only every alternate strip to form a sequence of strips, creating a twisted form.
steps.visual_description: Photo of a green pop-up card with horizontal slits, where alternate strips are lifted and twisted to create an undulating pattern.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Cut along the red lines. Lift and twist alternate strips to create the desired form.

projects.finished_product_description: A green pop-up card demonstrating a twisted form created by lifting only every alternate strip from a series of horizontal slits.

projects.name: Multi Slit Variation III: Splayed Strips

steps.instruction: Create multiple vertical slits in a sheet of cardstock. Instead of folding them in parallel, allow the strips to splay out to form a volumetric shape.
steps.visual_description: Photo of a blue pop-up card with vertical slits, where the strips are splayed outwards to form a fan-like, volumetric shape. The inside of the splayed strips appears white.

details.pattern: series of vertical slits arranged in a semi-circular pattern at the top

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Cut along the red lines. Allow the strips to splay outwards to create the desired form.

projects.finished_product_description: A blue pop-up card featuring vertical strips that are splayed out, creating a fan-like, volumetric structure.

projects.name: Multi Slit Variation IV: Layered Pop-up Platform

steps.instruction: Create a series of slits to form a platform. Note how a 'second generation' of pop-up elements is formed, supported by the initial series of strips. The pop-up looks good whether it is displayed on its base or side.
steps.visual_description: Photo of a red pop-up card with horizontal slits forming a layered, stepped platform with a 'second generation' of pop-up elements.

details.pattern: series of horizontal slits forming a stepped, arched pattern

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Cut along the red lines. Fold to create a layered platform with a second generation of pop-up elements.

projects.finished_product_description: A red pop-up card showcasing a layered, stepped platform created by a series of slits, including a 'second generation' of pop-up elements.

diagram_descriptions: Photo of an orange pop-up card (Variation I) with vertical strips folded into an asymmetric, twisted staircase.
Photo of a green pop-up card (Variation II) with horizontal slits, where alternate strips are lifted and twisted to create an undulating pattern.
Photo of a blue pop-up card (Variation III) with vertical slits, where the strips are splayed outwards to form a fan-like, volumetric shape.
Photo of a red pop-up card (Variation IV) with horizontal slits forming a layered, stepped platform with a 'second generation' of pop-up elements.
Blueprint diagram I: A rectangular outline with a V-shaped pattern of vertical red cut lines, flanked by green horizontal guide lines and vertical measurement indicators labeled 'I'.
Blueprint diagram II: A rectangular outline with a pattern of curved horizontal red cut lines, flanked by green horizontal guide lines and vertical measurement indicators labeled 'II'.
Blueprint diagram III: A rectangular outline with a semi-circular pattern of vertical red cut lines at the top, with vertical measurement indicators labeled 'III'.
Blueprint diagram IV: A rectangular outline with a stepped, arched pattern of horizontal red cut lines, flanked by green horizontal guide lines and vertical measurement indicators labeled 'IV'.

projects.name: Steps

materials.purpose: to stick to the back of the card

steps.instruction: Having carefully drawn the construction, cut along the parallel lines.
steps.visual_description: A hand using a craft knife to cut along red lines on a piece of paper that has a drawn staircase pattern.

steps.instruction: Use an indenting tool to go over all the creases, being careful to differentiate valleys from mountains. Then carefully form all the creases simultaneously to collapse the steps into their final shape.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a piece of paper with a cut and scored staircase pattern, collapsing it into shape.

steps.instruction: This is how the pop-up should look when the creasing is completed.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a partially folded paper staircase pop-up, showing the completed creasing.

steps.instruction: Finally, flatten the pop-up and press all the creases firmly.
steps.visual_description: Hands flattening a paper staircase pop-up and pressing the creases firmly.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Draw the steps according to the grid. Ensure accuracy. Differentiate mountain and valley creases. Collapse steps into final shape. Flatten and press creases.

tips: Note which of the distances are equal and how the mountain and valley creases touch the slits.
Your drawing must be extremely accurate.
For clarity, coloured lines have been used in this example to show which lines are for cutting and which for creasing.
projects.finished_product_description: A one-piece pop-up construction that forms a staircase.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a grid with measurements labeled A and B, where A is twice the length of B. Three parallel lines are marked with B.
Diagram showing a grid with a staircase pattern drawn with solid lines and dashed lines.
Diagram showing a staircase pattern with red lines indicating cuts and green lines indicating creases. Measurements A and B are indicated, with A being twice the length of B.

projects.name: Steps Variations

steps.instruction: Create a first generation of pop-up steps using cuts and folds. For example I, build a second generation of steps onto the first. Cut the front walls of both sets of steps away at 45 degrees to achieve a less weighty appearance.
steps.visual_description: Refer to Blueprint I for cut and fold lines. Photo I shows the finished pop-up with two generations of steps.

steps.instruction: Construct a simple stage set using the Steps technique. This involves creating a raised platform, steps, and a door cut-out. Ensure cuts are made beneath the stage and at the door.
steps.visual_description: Refer to Blueprint II for cut and fold lines. Photo II shows the finished pop-up stage set with a platform, steps, and a door.

steps.instruction: Create multiple generations of steps. If the first generation is large enough, a second generation can be built in the front. Further generations can also be made, as shown in Example III.
steps.visual_description: Refer to Blueprint III for cut and fold lines. Photo III shows a pop-up with multiple generations of steps arranged in a diamond pattern.

steps.instruction: Design and construct linked steps, allowing for intricate connected paths. This involves creating a main set of steps and branching or connecting additional steps.
steps.visual_description: Refer to Blueprint IV for cut and fold lines. Photo IV shows a pop-up with linked steps, demonstrating a main staircase and a smaller, connected one.

details.description: Complex pattern of cuts and folds forming a main set of steps and a smaller, second generation of steps built on top. Includes labels 'A', 'B', and 'IB' indicating specific points.
Cuts and folds forming a raised platform, a set of steps, and a rectangular opening (door) in the back wall. Includes labels 'A', 'B', and 'IB' indicating specific points.
Symmetrical pattern of many small rectangular cuts and folds forming a diamond or pyramid of steps. Includes small horizontal lines indicating fold points.
Cuts and folds forming two linked sets of steps, one larger and one smaller, with various 'A' and 'B' labels indicating specific points.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Green lines indicate folds, red lines indicate cuts. The diagrams show the patterns for creating various pop-up step structures.

tips: Note how both sets of steps appear less weighty than before because the front walls have been cut away at 45 degrees.
More complex scenery could be added at the back of the stage set.
Further generations of steps can be made if the first generation is large enough.
In more complex pop-ups, intricately connected paths can be traced up and down the steps.
projects.finished_product_description: Various pop-up card designs featuring different configurations of steps, including multi-generational steps, stage sets with doors, and intricately linked step paths.

projects.name: Wings

steps.instruction: Divide a sheet of stiff paper down the middle using a pencil. Draw two parallel lines equidistant and about 1-1.5 cm (Â½-Â¾ in) away from the centre. Draw two shapes (e.g., squares/rectangles as shown in the diagram), each beginning and ending on one of the outer lines. Erase any excess lines. (Red lines in the example indicate cuts, dotted lines indicate folds.)
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a rectangular sheet of paper with a central vertical green line, two additional green parallel lines 1-1.5 cm (Â½-Â¾ in) from the center, and two red square outlines drawn, one in each half, with one side aligned to the outer green lines. Dotted lines are also visible, indicating folds.

steps.instruction: Having carefully drawn the construction, make the two three-sided cuts.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a craft knife, cutting along three sides of a drawn square on a piece of paper placed on a cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Indent or score the valley creases, then pull the two shapes upwards.
steps.visual_description: Hands pulling up two cut shapes from the paper, revealing a pop-up effect, with creases visible. The shapes are pulled upwards from the main paper surface.

steps.instruction: Glue the top edges together so that the construction will fold flat when it is closed.
steps.visual_description: Hands applying glue to the top edges of the pulled-up shapes using a glue stick.

steps.instruction: Fold the pop-up in half so that the glued edge sticks firmly to the opposite surface.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding the paper in half, pressing down on the glued pop-up structure to secure it.

details.position: parallel to center, 1-1.5 cm (Â½-Â¾ in) from center on each side
two three-sided shapes (e.g., squares/rectangles) in each half, aligned with outer fold lines

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: This technique allows the outline of the two halves to be cut into almost any shape, and the halves may join in many ways, offering technical freedom. Glue is occasionally used.

tips: If the holes are a visual distraction, the card can be backed onto a sheet of paper the same colour.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card with two 'wing' shapes that stand up from the card base when opened, and fold flat when closed. The final image shows the pop-up structure from an angle, revealing the depth created by the folded and glued elements.

diagram_descriptions: Introductory diagram showing a rectangular sheet of paper with a central vertical green line, two additional green parallel lines 1-1.5 cm (Â½-Â¾ in) from the center, and two red square outlines drawn, one in each half, with one side aligned to the outer green lines. Dotted lines are also visible, indicating folds.
Photo for Step 1: Hands holding a craft knife, cutting along three sides of a drawn square on a piece of paper placed on a green cutting mat.
Photo for Step 2: Hands pulling up two cut shapes from the paper, revealing a pop-up effect, with creases visible. The shapes are pulled upwards from the main paper surface.
Photo for Step 3: Hands applying glue to the top edges of the pulled-up shapes using a yellow glue stick.
Photo for Step 4: Hands folding the paper in half, pressing down on the glued pop-up structure to secure it.

Large photo at the bottom of the page: A close-up, angled view of the finished pop-up structure, showing the two 'wings' standing up from the card base, with a pink background visible through the cutouts, demonstrating the three-dimensional effect.
