projects.name: Horizontal "V" I

steps.instruction: Crease a hem across the foot of a rectangle of stiff paper. This hem will be the glue tab and it must always be accurately made for the technique to work (see fig 1).
steps.visual_description: Hands creasing a narrow hem along the bottom edge of a light-colored rectangular piece of paper, placed on a green grid cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Unfold the hem so that you have a valley crease.
steps.visual_description: Hands unfolding the previously creased hem, revealing a distinct valley crease along the bottom edge of the paper.

steps.instruction: Fold the rectangle in half, so that if the hem crease is a valley, the new crease will be a mountain.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding the paper in half vertically, perpendicular to the existing hem crease, creating a new central crease.

steps.instruction: Unfold it. Make a slit up the mid crease to the hem crease to separate the hem into two 'feet'. This is the basic unit, ready to be glued to its backing sheet.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding the unfolded paper, which now shows a vertical slit extending from the central fold line up to the hem crease, effectively dividing the hem into two distinct 'feet'.

steps.instruction: Close the pop-up and apply glue to the underside of both feet.
steps.visual_description: Hands applying glue from a yellow glue stick to the underside of the two 'feet' of the pop-up unit, which is in a closed position.

steps.instruction: Very carefully glue one foot to the backing crease so that the point of the base of the pop-up where the feet meet exactly touches the gutter crease on the backing sheet. Note that the second foot is on top of the construction, glue side up.
steps.visual_description: Hands carefully gluing one of the pop-up unit's 'feet' to a backing sheet. The base point where the feet meet is aligned precisely with a crease on the backing sheet. The second foot is shown resting on top, with its glue side facing up.

details.position: from vertical center crease up to hem crease

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The pop-up unit has two 'feet' created by a slit. One foot is glued to the backing sheet, aligning the base point with a crease. The second foot is on top, glue side up, to be glued down later.

tips: This technique is the simplest and most useful of all multi-piece techniques.
Almost any reasonably sturdy, self-supporting shape can be made to stand with the simple addition of glue tabs across the bottom and a vertical crease.

There are two basic ways to fix the pop-up shape to the backing sheet: 1) glue tabs across the bottom are glued directly onto the backing sheet; 2) tabs are pushed through slots to lie neatly out of sight beneath the backing sheet.
The first method (gluing tabs directly) is simpler but leaves glue tabs visible on the surface of the backing sheet, which can be unsightly if the papers do not match.
The hem (glue tab) must always be accurately made for the technique to work.
projects.finished_product_description: A basic pop-up unit with two 'feet' ready to be attached to a backing sheet, forming a horizontal 'V' shape when opened.

diagram_descriptions: Fig 1: A diagram of a rectangular piece of paper showing a green dashed line near the bottom edge representing the hem/glue tab, and a red dashed line vertically down the center representing the mid crease. A small vertical slit is shown from the bottom edge up to the green dashed line, centered on the red dashed line, indicating the separation of the hem into two 'feet'.
Photo 1: A close-up of hands creasing a narrow hem along the bottom edge of a light-colored rectangular piece of paper, placed on a green grid cutting mat.
Photo 2: A close-up of hands unfolding the previously creased hem, revealing a distinct valley crease along the bottom edge of the paper.
Photo 3: A close-up of hands folding the paper in half vertically, perpendicular to the existing hem crease, creating a new central crease.

Photo 4: A close-up of hands holding the unfolded paper, which now shows a vertical slit extending from the central fold line up to the hem crease, effectively dividing the hem into two distinct 'feet'.
Photo 5: A close-up of hands applying glue from a yellow glue stick to the underside of the two 'feet' of the pop-up unit, which is in a closed position.

Photo 6: A close-up of hands carefully gluing one of the pop-up unit's 'feet' to a backing sheet. The base point where the feet meet is aligned precisely with a crease on the backing sheet. The second foot is shown resting on top, with its glue side facing up.

projects.name: Victorian Man

steps.instruction: Fold the backing sheet in half so that the second glued foot sticks to the empty side of the sheet.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a piece of paper in half, with one hand pressing down on a glued section.

steps.instruction: Press down on the pop-up to strengthen the adhesion of both feet to the backing sheet, then open it up.
steps.visual_description: Hands pressing down on a folded piece of paper, which is part of a pop-up mechanism.

A pop-up mechanism folded flat, showing the two feet that will be at equal angles on either side of the gutter crease.
A detailed view of the finished Victorian Man pop-up, showing the head, collar, and tie constructed from layered paper.

projects.name: Horizontal "V" II

materials.details: pre-made from steps 1 to 3 of the previous method (see fig 1, page 70)

steps.instruction: Begin with the basic pop-up form, made in steps 1 to 3 of the previous method (see fig 1, page 70).
steps.visual_description: Photo shows two hands holding a small, folded white paper pop-up unit, forming a basic 'V' shape, on a green cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Cut away the central area of the glue tabs. The precise amount cut off is unimportant, but neither tab should encroach too closely on the mid crease (see fig 2).
steps.visual_description: Photo shows two hands holding the folded paper from step 1, with the central part of the glue tabs cut out. Two small rectangular paper scraps and a red craft knife are visible on the green mat.

steps.instruction: On the backing sheet, use a protractor to measure equal angles each side of the gutter so that they form a "V". Draw in the angles. (For clarity, coloured lines have been used in this example, but you should draw them in pencil.)
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a hand using a protractor to draw lines on a white backing sheet, forming a 'V' shape. The sheet is on a green cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Turn the backing sheet over and cut slots to correspond with the positions and lengths of the glue tabs on the pop-up unit.
dimensions_mentioned: positions and lengths of the glue tabs
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a hand using a red craft knife to cut two short, parallel slots into the folded white backing sheet. The sheet is on a green cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Turn the backing sheet over again and push the glue tabs through the slots.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a hand pushing the glue tabs of the pop-up unit through the slots cut in the backing sheet, inserting it from underneath.

steps.instruction: Fasten each tab flat with a length of sticky tape or glue. Open out the sheet.
steps.visual_description: Photo shows a hand applying a piece of clear sticky tape over one of the glue tabs on the underside of the backing sheet, securing it. The sheet is on a green cutting mat.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The glue tabs of the pop-up unit are pushed through slots in the backing sheet and secured from behind. The central sections of the tabs are cut away to prevent them from meeting at the gutter crease, ensuring a stronger backing sheet and hiding the tabs for a neater finish.

tips: Draw lines in pencil for clarity, even if colored lines are shown in examples.
projects.finished_product_description: An open pop-up card featuring a 'V' shaped pop-up unit, with its glue tabs hidden beneath the backing sheet for a neater finish.

diagram_descriptions: Photo showing two hands holding a small, folded white paper pop-up unit, forming a basic 'V' shape, on a green cutting mat.

Photo showing a hand using a protractor to draw 'V' shaped lines on a white backing sheet, on a green cutting mat.
Photo showing a hand using a red craft knife to cut two short, parallel slots into the folded white backing sheet, on a green cutting mat.
Photo showing a hand pushing the glue tabs of the pop-up unit through the slots cut in the backing sheet, inserting it from underneath.
Photo showing a hand applying a piece of clear sticky tape over one of the glue tabs on the underside of the backing sheet, securing it.

projects.name: Floating Layers

steps.instruction: Fold each strip, as shown here. If the horizontal creases are mountains, fold a valley down the centre. Make a slit up the mid crease of each strip, to separate the hem and create two "feet".
steps.visual_description: Hands folding an orange paper strip into a zig-zag shape, then making a cut up the center fold to create two 'feet'.

steps.instruction: For each support, apply glue to one half of the inner face.
steps.visual_description: Hands applying glue from a glue stick to the inner face of one half of an orange paper support.

steps.instruction: Close the support, pressing the two faces together. This shows one support complete.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a completed orange paper support, showing the two folded faces pressed together.

steps.instruction: Carefully glue the base of one support exactly over the gutter crease on the backing sheet.
steps.visual_description: Hands gluing the base of an orange paper support onto a yellow backing sheet, aligning it with the center crease.

steps.instruction: Glue down the other two, in line with the first support.
steps.visual_description: Hands gluing two more orange paper supports onto a yellow backing sheet, in line with the first support.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The Floating Layers effect has two elements: the supports and the layer itself. They are made separately. First make the backing sheet, then start constructing this design by making the supports, and follow with the layer afterwards. As the variations that follow the step-by-step sequence show, the Floating Layers principle can be applied in many ways, though there must always be at least three supports, one along the gutter crease and one to each side.

projects.finished_product_description: Forms that appear to float unsupported in mid-air.

Diagram showing three smaller rectangles arranged horizontally, each with two horizontal red lines indicating creases.

Photograph showing hands applying glue from a glue stick to the inner face of one half of an orange paper support.
Photograph showing a hand holding a completed orange paper support, with the two folded faces pressed together.
Photograph showing hands gluing the base of an orange paper support onto a yellow backing sheet, aligning it with the center crease.
Photograph showing hands gluing two more orange paper supports onto a yellow backing sheet, in line with the first support.

projects.name: Multi-Piece Floating Layer Pop-Up

steps.instruction: Cut the floating layer out of a sheet of stiff paper. It should be large enough to cover the supports. Crease it down the middle. Apply glue to the central support only and carefully join the central crease of the layer to the central crease of the support.
dimensions_mentioned: large enough to cover the supports
steps.visual_description: A pair of hands holding a dark grey rectangular paper (the floating layer) and aligning its central crease with the central orange support, which is already attached to a yellow base paper. Two other orange supports are visible on the base.

steps.instruction: Apply glue to the other supports, then flatten all three to the left, being careful not to let the glue touch the underside of the floating layer.
steps.visual_description: A pair of hands applying glue to the two outer orange supports. The green floating layer is partially attached to the central support, and the supports are flattened towards the left side of the yellow base paper.

steps.instruction: Lower the layer onto the glued supports so that the whole structure is flat. Then carefully pull it upright.
steps.visual_description: A pair of hands pressing down on the green floating layer, which is now fully glued to all three orange supports, making the entire structure lie flat on the yellow base paper.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The floating layer is attached to three supports, which are then attached to a base sheet. The floating layer is creased down the middle and attached to the central crease of the central support. The supports are designed to flatten when the structure is closed and pop up when opened.

tips: Although the method may seem lengthy, it is not difficult.
The unsightly feet at the base of the supports can be made invisible if the backing sheet is slit and the feet pushed through.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up structure featuring a green rectangular floating layer with a central crease, supported by three orange rectangular supports, all mounted on a yellow base sheet. The structure is designed to flatten when closed and pop up when opened.

The third photo shows hands pressing down on a green paper fully attached to three orange supports, flattened onto a yellow base. Below these, a large photo displays the completed pop-up structure: a green rectangular layer with a central crease, supported by three orange rectangular supports, all standing upright on a yellow base sheet.

projects.name: Straps

steps.instruction: Cut out a rectangle of stiff paper. Add a central mountain crease and two equidistant valleys.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a piece of paper with a central crease and two side creases.

steps.instruction: Glue the strap onto a sturdy backing sheet so that the mountain crease lies directly over the gutter crease. This is the strap complete.
steps.visual_description: Hands gluing a folded paper strap onto a larger sheet of paper. A glue stick is visible.

steps.instruction: To complete the off-centre effect, glue Horizontal "V" walls (see page 70) across the valley creases. Note that the strap is flat across the gutter crease.
steps.visual_description: A paper structure with two pink V-shaped elements glued onto a base, with a folded strap visible underneath. The V-shaped elements are positioned across valley creases.

tips: The extra valley creases generated by a strap can be used to power pop-ups of any technique; Horizontal "V", Floating Layers and so forth.

projects.name: Diagonal Box

steps.instruction: Having drawn the diagram, cut out the box shape. Next, fold the panels, creasing the red lines as mountain folds and the green lines as valley folds.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a net for a box with fold lines indicated by colored lines (red for mountain, green for valley) and glue tabs at the bottom.

steps.instruction: Fold the panels to create a square tube. Glue the end tab to secure the shape.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding the cut-out paper into a square tube shape and gluing an end tab.

steps.instruction: Glue the underside of the remaining tabs. Open the tube to a perfect square, so that the gutter crease on the backing sheet connects exactly with opposite corners of the square, then press the glued tabs to the backing sheet and push them through out of sight.
steps.visual_description: A partially assembled pop-up box on a teal backing sheet, showing tabs being glued. The box is open to a square shape.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The box is attached to a backing sheet via tabs. The gutter crease of the box aligns with the corners of the backing sheet.

tips: The taller the tube becomes, the less upright it will stand.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up box that forms a tulip when the card is opened. The box is made from four flat sheets of card slotted together.

diagram_descriptions: A diagram showing the net for a box with fold lines indicated by colored lines (red for mountain, green for valley) and glue tabs at the bottom.
A photograph of a pop-up tulip emerging from a card.
A photograph showing hands folding a cut-out paper shape into a square tube.
A photograph showing a partially assembled pop-up box on a teal backing sheet, with tabs being glued.
A photograph of the finished pop-up box attached to a teal backing sheet.

projects.name: Diagonal Box Variations

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Diagram shows how the box, scenery flat support, interlocking triangle, right-hand triangle, and scenery triangle fit together.

projects.finished_product_description: Various box structures with pop-up elements and scenery.

diagram_descriptions: Photo of a pop-up box with a tall 'X' form inside, made of dark grey cardstock.
Photo of a pop-up box with angled scenery elements made of pink and blue cardstock.
Photo of a simple wooden box on a light blue surface.
Diagram showing two T-shaped paper pieces labeled 'I' with dimensions A and B, indicating glue tabs and fold lines.
Diagram showing a rectangular paper piece labeled 'I' with dimensions A and B, indicating glue tabs and fold lines.
Diagram showing a rectangular paper piece labeled 'III' with dimensions A and B, indicating glue tabs and fold lines.

Diagram showing a rectangular paper piece labeled 'scenery flat support' with dimensions A and B, indicating glue tabs and fold lines.
Diagram showing a right-angled triangle labeled 'right-hand triangle'.
Diagram showing a triangle labeled 'interlocking triangle' with dimension B, and fold lines.

projects.name: Square-on Box

steps.instruction: Having drawn the diagram, cut out the shape, then fold the panels to create a square tube.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a pre-cut paper shape into a square tube.

steps.instruction: Glue the end tab so that the box can stand square over the gutter crease. Fold the panels to secure the shape.
steps.visual_description: A partially formed square box with a tab being glued to a crease. Hands are shown folding the panels.

steps.instruction: Glue the underside of the remaining tabs. Pull the tabs apart to stretch the tube square, then lower it onto a backing sheet in such a way that the two creases running down the middle of the tube line up exactly with the gutter crease. Press the glued tabs onto the backing sheet.
steps.visual_description: Hands are shown gluing tabs on the underside of a square tube. The tube is then positioned onto a backing sheet, aligning creases.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Diagram shows layout for cutting and folding a square tube. Red lines indicate valley folds, green lines indicate mountain folds.

tips: The box can be any proportion, but should not be more than one-and-a-half times higher than its width across the gutter crease. If too tall, the sides begin to collapse inwards and look ungainly.
projects.finished_product_description: A pink, partially formed square box standing on a white surface.

projects.name: Truck
tips: Though essentially a pop-up made using the Square-on Box technique, this construction could also perhaps have been described as being made using the Floating Layers technique; just visible are vertical supports rising from the gutter crease to the top surfaces of the truck. Note the exhaust pipes, wing mirrors and recessed wheels made using the Cut Away technique. The surface was rendered with marker pens.
projects.finished_product_description: A yellow and grey paper model of a truck, with red stripes on the cab. It is shown on a white pop-up base.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a rectangular strip with lines indicating mountain and valley folds, and tabs labeled 'A' at the ends.
Photograph of hands folding a paper shape into a square tube.
Photograph of a partially formed square box with a tab being glued.
Photograph of hands gluing tabs on the underside of a square tube and positioning it onto a backing sheet.
A pink, partially formed square box standing on a white surface.
A yellow and grey paper model of a truck with red stripes, shown on a white pop-up base.

projects.name: Square-on Box Variations

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Assemble box, lid, and central support as shown in the exploded diagram.

projects.finished_product_description: Three variations of pop-up boxes: a hexagonal box, a cylinder, and a solid box, with a lid and central support mechanism.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram I shows a flat, rectangular piece of paper with vertical green fold lines and horizontal red fold lines, and dotted glue tabs on the right edge. It is labeled 'I (LEFT)'.
Diagram II shows a flat, rectangular piece of paper with vertical green fold lines and a horizontal red fold line in the center. It is labeled 'II (CENTRE)'.
Diagram III shows a flat, rectangular piece of paper with vertical green fold lines and horizontal red fold lines, and dotted glue tabs on the right edge. It is labeled 'III (RIGHT)'.
Diagram showing a flat, rectangular piece of paper with vertical green fold lines and horizontal red fold lines, and dotted glue tabs on the bottom. It is labeled 'box'.

Diagram showing two flat, square pieces of paper with vertical green fold lines and horizontal red fold lines, and dotted glue tabs on the sides. One piece is larger than the other. They are labeled 'central support'.
Diagram showing a flat, square piece of paper with vertical green fold lines and horizontal red fold lines, and dotted glue tabs on the sides. It is labeled 'lid'.
Exploded view diagram showing a box, a lid, and a central support mechanism, with arrows indicating how they assemble onto a flat base. Labels indicate 'box', 'lid', and 'central support'.

projects.name: Cylinder

steps.instruction: Having drawn up the backing sheet, fold the gutter crease and cut a slot along the left-hand line (A), a little larger than the width of the cylinder arm.
steps.visual_description: A piece of paper folded in half with a vertical line drawn on the inside.

steps.instruction: Fold over the tabs on the cylinder and apply glue to them.
steps.visual_description: A T-shaped piece of paper with tabs being folded over and glue being applied to them.

steps.instruction: Fix the glued tabs to the backing sheet along the right-hand vertical line, having first folded the strap on the cylinder under the cylinder block and between the glued tabs, so that it protrudes to the left, as shown.
steps.visual_description: Hands are shown attaching a folded piece of paper to a backing sheet, with a strap protruding.

steps.instruction: Fold the backing sheet in half. Tuck the protruding strap through the slot.
steps.visual_description: A backing sheet is folded in half, and a strap is being tucked through a slot.

steps.instruction: Secure the arm with a piece of masking or sticky tape.
steps.visual_description: A piece of tape is being applied to secure a folded paper structure.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The cylinder arm is folded under and secured through a slot in the backing sheet. Tabs on the cylinder are glued to the backing sheet.

tips: Cut out the shape of the cylinder, as shown. The length of the arm is not critical, although it is always better to overestimate its length than underestimate; the excess can be cut off later.
Using a pencil, draw a line down the centre of the backing sheet. Then draw two lines parallel to the first. Note that A is closer to the centre line than B. This is important.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up element that forms a cylinder when opened.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing the shape to be cut out for the cylinder, with dotted lines indicating where to fold and solid green lines indicating cut lines. It has a main rectangular body with a smaller rectangular arm extending from one side, and tabs on the ends of the arm.
Diagram of a rectangle with a dashed vertical line down the center, and two solid vertical lines parallel to the center line, labeled A and B, with A being closer to the center line.

projects.name: Kiosque au Jardin
tips: This charming design, made by laminating colour photocopies of original artwork onto card (cardboard), uses the basic Cylinder technique, except that the pull tab is pushed through a slot, to continue behind the kiosk attendant, emerging through another slot and connecting with the right-hand edge of the cylinder. In this way, the artwork inside the kiosk is uninterrupted by the tab.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up kiosk in a garden scene.

diagram_descriptions: Above: A pop-up card depicting a garden scene with a kiosk, flowers, and trees. The kiosk has a blue, scaled roof and a girl inside. The garden has potted plants and a statue.
Left: A flat piece of card (cardboard) with a rolled section and a tab, showing how the mechanism works when the card is opened.

projects.name: Trellises

steps.instruction: On two pieces of stiff paper and using a pencil, draw the diagrams, carefully noting each of the measurements. Having drawn the diagrams, cut out the two shapes.
steps.visual_description: Photo of hands holding a light blue, cut-out paper piece (the larger trellis piece) against a green cutting mat. The paper piece has multiple folds and cut slits.

steps.instruction: Glue the larger of the two pieces into a rectangular tube.
steps.visual_description: Photo of hands applying glue to one end of the larger paper piece, forming it into a rectangular tube shape. A glue stick is visible on the green cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Interlock the smaller piece into the larger using the slits.
steps.visual_description: Photo of hands inserting the smaller, folded paper piece into the larger rectangular tube, aligning the pre-cut slits.

pieces.name: Larger Trellis Piece
pieces.shape: complex polygon (long strip with a central rectangular section and two trapezoidal end sections)

details.position: vertical, defining sections A and B
details.label: A, B

details.position: four vertical slits within the 'A' sections
details.label: C (height of slits)

details.position: two vertical slits on each end
details.label: C (height of slits)

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Coloured lines (green for folding, red for cutting) are used in the diagrams. The larger piece is glued to form a rectangular tube. The smaller piece is then interlocked into the larger tube using the slits.

tips: The only constant factor is that when erected and viewed from above, the slats must form a series of 90-degree intersections.
If they do not cross at right angles the construction will not flatten.
The distances between the slits must be measured precisely.
projects.finished_product_description: A truly sculptural form, presenting the pop-up as a free-standing object in its own right. The different heights of the three layers allows each to be seen.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing the pattern for the larger trellis piece, a long strip with a central rectangular section and two trapezoidal end sections. It is labeled with relative measurements A, B, and C. Green lines indicate folds, and red lines indicate cuts (slits).
Diagram showing the pattern for the smaller trellis piece, a simple rectangle. It is labeled with relative measurements B and C. Red lines indicate cuts (slits) on the ends.
Photo showing the finished Trellises structure, a multi-layered pop-up, viewed from the side, highlighting the distinct heights of its three layers.

projects.name: Chess Game

steps.instruction: Slot together 18 identical strips of card (cardboard) without glue to create a chessboard using the Trellis technique.
steps.visual_description: A chessboard made of interlocking strips of card, with black and white squares. Chess pieces are placed on the board.

steps.instruction: The chess pieces slot onto the strips and can be moved about as in an ordinary game; they stay attached to the board when it is collapsed.
steps.visual_description: Close-up of chess pieces (king, knight, rook) on the constructed chessboard.

tips: The units need not be identical, and they can be of any shape and interlock in an irregular pattern, providing that all the units interlock at 90 degrees when three-dimensional.
projects.finished_product_description: A collapsible chessboard with pieces that slot onto the board.

templates.name: Interlocking Unit Template
templates.shape_description: Rectangular strips with interlocking notches. One template shows a shape with three notches on the top edge and two on the bottom. Another template shows a similar shape with four notches on the top edge and three on the bottom. A third template shows a simpler rectangular strip with two notches on the top edge and two on the bottom.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing three different templates for interlocking units. The top template has dimensions indicated by arrows and colored lines (red and green). The middle template has similar markings. The bottom template is labeled 'x 10' and shows a simple rectangular strip with two notches on the top and two on the bottom.
A 3D illustration of several interlocking paper units of varying heights, forming a decorative arrangement.
A 3D illustration of a large grid structure made from interlocking purple strips, forming many square cells.

projects.name: Pivots

steps.instruction: Following the diagrams, cut out a triangular tab and pivot. Fold the tab, creating one valley and two mountain creases.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a small triangular shape with a central red line (valley crease) and two green lines (mountain creases) forming a 'W' shape when viewed from the side, and a separate long rectangular strip with a dotted area at one end.

steps.instruction: Glue the tab to the gutter crease, ensuring the central mountain fold and the gutter crease are exactly in line.
steps.visual_description: Photo of hands gluing a small, light blue folded paper tab onto a white card, aligning it with a crease.

steps.instruction: The long arm, which is to pivot, will do so with the greatest sweep if it is glued to one face of the triangular tab so that it rises perpendicularly away from the crease at the bottom of the face.
steps.visual_description: Photo of hands gluing a light brown rectangular paper strip (the long arm) onto one face of the previously glued light blue triangular tab on a white card.

pieces.name: triangular tab
pieces.shape: triangular shape designed to fold into a W-shape

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The triangular tab is folded with one valley and two mountain creases. The tab is glued to the gutter crease. The long arm is glued to one face of the triangular tab to create the pivot mechanism.

tips: The Pivot technique can work on any crease (valley or mountain). It will work better if the opening crease opens from 0 to 180 degrees, and if the triangular tab lies almost flat across a crease.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up mechanism that swivels as the gutter crease is opened, allowing an element to rise perpendicularly from the crease. Pivots are often used in a humorous context and require attention to the shape, length, and position of the long arm to prevent jamming or creasing.

projects.name: DARTBOARD
tips: A pop-up need not be technically advanced to be memorable; the illustration can be just as important.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a dartboard with darts standing away from its surface, created using a simple pivot mechanism. The dartboard is rendered with eye-catching detail using coloured pencils, gouache, and chalk. The finished card has a height of 23 cm (9 in).

templates.name: Triangular Tab for Pivot
templates.shape_description: A small, flat, roughly triangular paper piece with a central red solid line (valley crease) and two outer green solid lines (mountain creases), indicating folds for a pivot mechanism.

templates.name: Long Arm for Pivot
templates.shape_description: A long, flat, rectangular paper strip with a dotted area at one end, representing the 'long arm' of the pivot mechanism.

diagram_descriptions: Photo of a finished pop-up card showing a dartboard with three darts embedded, standing away from the card surface, created using the pivot technique. The card is white, and the dartboard is colorful with black, yellow, red, and green sections, numbered 1 to 20.
Diagram showing a small, flat, roughly triangular paper piece with a central red solid line (valley crease) and two outer green solid lines (mountain creases), indicating folds for a pivot mechanism.
Diagram showing a long, flat, rectangular paper strip with a dotted area at one end, representing the 'long arm' of the pivot mechanism.
Photo of hands gluing a small, light blue folded paper tab (the triangular tab) onto the gutter crease of a white card, ensuring alignment.
Photo of hands gluing a light brown rectangular paper strip (the long arm) onto one face of the previously glued light blue triangular tab on a white card, demonstrating the assembly of the pivot.

projects.name: Pivots Variations

materials.color: white, pink, light blue, brown (as shown)

steps.instruction: Make a horizontal Asymmetric Mountain Step form (refer to page 49 for the base structure). Add a V-shaped creased triangle, extending it to create a large pivoting arm. Glue this step across the gutter crease. When the backing sheet is closed, the arm will swivel to lie vertically.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a white paper shape with a rounded top-left corner, a horizontal step, and a V-shaped crease (red lines) extending into a vertical arm. Green dotted lines indicate glue areas along the right edge and bottom of the step.

steps.instruction: Note that the pivot mechanism can be repeated at the bottom end of the mountain crease, and other pivots can be placed across the valley creases.
steps.visual_description: Photo of hands holding an open white card with multiple pink paper elements folded and pivoted, demonstrating variations of the pivot mechanism.

steps.instruction: Observe how an added flap can be used to hide the pivoting arm.
steps.visual_description: Photo of hands holding an open white card with pink and light blue paper elements. A light blue flap is shown covering part of a pink pivoting arm.

steps.instruction: In 'Variation I', the arm is initially in view all the time. However, if you add a large flap, stuck to the step, it will hide the arm when the card is closed, allowing it to swivel amusingly into view as it is opened.
steps.visual_description: Photo of an open white card with a single brown pivoting arm attached to a light blue base, extending upwards at an angle. Below this, a diagram shows a rectangular shape with a V-crease and a vertical arm, similar to the first diagram but simpler, and another plain rectangle below it.

pieces.name: Asymmetric Mountain Step with Pivoting Arm
pieces.shape: complex, L-shaped with a rounded top-left corner and a horizontal step

details.position: V-shaped, extending into a vertical arm
along the right edge and bottom of the step
V-shaped, extending into a vertical arm

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The main step is glued across the gutter crease of a backing sheet. The arm swivels vertically when the backing sheet is closed. Flaps can be added to conceal the arm.

tips: The pivot mechanism can be repeated at the bottom end of the mountain crease.
Other pivots can be placed across the valley creases.
Adding a large flap, stuck to the step, can hide the arm when the card is closed, creating an amusing reveal when opened.
projects.finished_product_description: An interactive paper card featuring various pivoting mechanisms that reveal elements as the card is opened, with options for concealed or always-visible arms.

diagram_descriptions: Photo of hands holding an open white card with multiple pink paper elements folded and pivoted, demonstrating variations of the pivot mechanism.
Photo of hands holding an open white card with pink and light blue paper elements. A light blue flap is shown covering part of a pink pivoting arm.
Photo of an open white card with a single brown pivoting arm attached to a light blue base, extending upwards at an angle.

Diagram showing a white paper shape with a rounded top-left corner, a horizontal step, and a V-shaped crease (red lines) extending into a vertical arm. Green dotted lines indicate glue areas along the right edge and bottom of the step.
Diagram showing a rectangular shape with a V-crease (red lines) and a vertical arm, illustrating a simplified pivoting arm mechanism. Below it, a plain rectangle is shown.

A page with abstract paper sculptures creating geometric shapes and shadows. The main elements are folded paper planes and boxes, creating a sense of depth and three-dimensionality. There is text at the top of the page which appears to be a title or heading.

templates.name: heart templates
templates.shape_description: heart

diagram_descriptions: A geometric pop-up structure made of folded paper, resembling a diamond shape when closed, with sharp creases and facets. The background is a textured, light green paper.

projects.name: WATERFALLS OF THE SIERRA NEVADA
projects.finished_product_description: This concertina pop-up stands some 6 m (6Â½ yd) tall when suspended. Its zig-zag shape is held in place by running threads which pull taut when the pop-up is suspended; without them they would flatten. The pop-up will collapse flat and is housed in the box seen beneath it, though the box is not part of the display. This beautiful pop-up is decorated with water-colour, gold pen, cotton and reflective foil.

diagram_descriptions: A small illustration of a heart with an arrow through it, next to the text.
A small illustration of two interlocking hearts, next to the text.

projects.name: Design One

steps.instruction: Fold a sheet of paper in half and press the gutter crease firmly.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a light-colored sheet of paper in half on a light blue grid mat, pressing the fold.

steps.instruction: Fold it in half again, then unfold it completely.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding the already once-folded paper in half again on a light blue grid mat.

steps.instruction: Fold the paper in half, in the same way that you did for step 1. Then draw a half-heart shape from the gutter crease. Cut through both layers of paper, but leave a small part uncut.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding the folded paper, with scissors cutting along a drawn half-heart shape originating from the gutter crease.

steps.instruction: This photograph shows the cut out heart. Be careful not to tear the small join.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding the folded paper, revealing the cut-out half-heart shape still attached by a small uncut join.

steps.instruction: Unfold the paper, then fold it along the central horizontal line, so that the heart is in the front.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding the paper, now unfolded to show a full heart shape cut into the center, with a central horizontal fold line visible.

steps.instruction: Form the pop-up by lifting the heart up and creating a mountain fold down the centre of the gutter crease.
steps.visual_description: Hands manipulating the paper to lift the heart, forming a pop-up effect with a mountain fold at the center of the gutter crease.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The heart is formed by cutting a half-heart shape from the folded paper, leaving a small join. The pop-up is created by unfolding and then folding along a central horizontal line, lifting the heart to form a mountain fold at the gutter crease.

tips: Be careful not to tear the small join when cutting the heart.
By doubling over the paper at the back, the construction becomes surprisingly sturdy.
This project uses the 'Shape of Slit' technique (see page 26 for more details).
The heart templates shown in this chapter can be enlarged, but the different elements of the designs must remain in proportion to each other.
The techniques used here, while relating to a heart shape, can be adapted to represent any other subject with imagination.
projects.finished_product_description: A simple, sturdy pop-up heart made from medium-weight, marble-effect paper, created using the Shape of Slit technique, where the heart pops up from the center of the card.

diagram_descriptions: A finished red pop-up heart standing upright on a white card, viewed from a slight angle.
Photo 1: Hands folding a light-colored sheet of paper in half on a light blue grid mat, pressing the fold.
Photo 2: Hands folding the already once-folded paper in half again on a light blue grid mat.
Photo 3: Hands holding the folded paper, with scissors cutting along a drawn half-heart shape originating from the gutter crease.
Photo 4: Hands holding the folded paper, revealing the cut-out half-heart shape still attached by a small uncut join.
Photo 5: Hands holding the paper, now unfolded to show a full heart shape cut into the center, with a central horizontal fold line visible.
Photo 6: Hands manipulating the paper to lift the heart, forming a pop-up effect with a mountain fold at the center of the gutter crease.

projects.name: Design Two

steps.instruction: Close the card and reinforce all the creases by pressing firmly.
steps.visual_description: Hands pressing a folded card on a grid mat.

tips: Experiment with different thicknesses. Use thick paper or thin card (cardboard).
This card was decorated using oil pastel over the heart and gouache to enhance the marble-effect.
Draw a line down the middle of the paper, then add three vertical lines so that the measurements between the lines are exactly equal, as shown.

Draw a heart and tab using the vertical lines as positional guides, and note that the heart is off-centre. Erase the excess lines, such as the gutter crease inside the heart, then cut and crease following the colour coding.
The card looks at its best when viewed, not symmetrically, but a little to one side so that the heart is square-on.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card with a heart cut out of the front layer. The heart is off-centre and decorated with a marble effect.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up card with two heart shapes cut out, one larger and one smaller, against a blue background.
Diagram showing a rectangle with a vertical center line and three equally spaced vertical lines.
Diagram showing a rectangle with vertical lines and a heart shape with a tab, positioned off-centre.
A close-up of a pop-up card with a single heart cut out, showing the marble-effect decoration.

projects.name: Design Three

steps.instruction: Mark a line down the middle of the card, then add three more vertical lines.
steps.visual_description: A rectangle with a vertical line down the center and three additional vertical lines spaced evenly.

steps.instruction: Draw the heart-like shape and tab. Note that the two halves of the heart do not meet square-on. Erase the central part of the gutter crease, then cut and crease, following the colour coding.
steps.visual_description: A rectangle with a heart shape drawn inside. The heart has a tab on the right side. Several horizontal lines are also drawn across the rectangle.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Cut and crease following the colour coding. Erase central part of gutter crease.

projects.finished_product_description: A card with a heart shape that pierces the plane of the card, decorated with red gouache spray and an overpainted red heart.

projects.name: Design Four

steps.instruction: Mark a line across the centre of the paper, then add three horizontal lines so that the distances between each pair of lines is exactly equal.
steps.visual_description: A rectangle with a horizontal line across the center and three additional horizontal lines spaced evenly.

steps.instruction: Draw the design. Erase all excess lines, then cut and crease to form the pop-up, following the colour coding.
steps.visual_description: A rectangle with a heart shape drawn inside. The heart has a tab on the right side. Several horizontal lines are also drawn across the rectangle.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Cut and crease to form the pop-up, following the colour coding. Erase all excess lines.

projects.finished_product_description: A card with a pop-up heart silhouette created using the Cut Away technique, decorated with a red marker pen.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a rectangle with vertical lines, indicating where to cut and fold for a pop-up card.
Diagram showing a rectangle with a heart shape and horizontal lines, indicating where to cut and fold for a pop-up card.
Photograph of a finished pop-up card with a red heart that pierces the plane of the card, showing a three-dimensional structure.
Photograph of a finished pop-up card with a red heart silhouette on a stepped pop-up mechanism, decorated with red squiggly lines.

projects.name: Design Five

tools.name: ruler
tools.purpose: drawing straight lines and measuring equal distances

steps.instruction: Draw a line down the middle of the card. Add two more vertical lines, one on each side of the central line, ensuring that the distances between these lines are exactly equal.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular card with three parallel vertical lines. The central line is in the middle, and the other two are equidistant from it.

steps.instruction: Draw the heart design as shown, taking care to match up each part of the shape with the correct vertical line. Note that the two halves of the heart are not totally aligned. Erase all excess lines. Then, cut along the indicated lines (red) and crease along the indicated lines (green) to form the pop-up, following the colour codes.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular card with the three vertical lines. A heart shape is drawn within the central section, with its two halves slightly offset. Red lines indicate cuts, and green lines indicate creases for the pop-up mechanism.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Cut and crease the heart shape into the card base to create a pop-up effect. The heart is turned sideways with a step on each side.

tips: Use thick paper or thin card (cardboard) for durability.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a heart shape that is turned sideways with a step on each side. The example uses a red matt card for the pop-up heart against a pearl blue background card. The unique cuts and creases pattern creates an original and unexpected pop-up form.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing the initial drawing of three equidistant vertical lines on a card.
Diagram showing the heart design drawn onto the card, indicating cut lines (red) and crease lines (green) for the pop-up mechanism, with the two halves of the heart slightly misaligned.

Photograph of the finished pop-up card, open to reveal a red heart with yellow accents, popping out from a pearl blue card base. The heart is designed with a sideways orientation and steps on each side.

projects.name: Design Six

steps.instruction: Using a craft knife, carefully cut out the heart and stem.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a white card and a red heart shape, with a craft knife cutting the heart and stem from the card.

steps.instruction: Form two valley creases at the base of the stem by folding backwards and forwards.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a white card with a red heart attached by a stem. The stem is being creased.

steps.instruction: Unfold the card and lift up the heart and stem; note the valley creases.
steps.visual_description: Hands unfolding a white card to reveal a red heart pop-up element attached by a stem. Valley creases are visible at the base of the stem.

steps.instruction: Crease the "V"-shaped fold at the top of the stem so that the heart swivels to the horizontal. Note how the crease down the centre of the heart becomes a valley.
steps.visual_description: Hands creasing the V-shaped fold at the top of the stem of the heart pop-up element. The heart is shown swiveling horizontally.

steps.instruction: Complete the pop-up by folding down the edges of the backing sheet.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding down the edges of a white backing sheet to complete a pop-up card with a red heart.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Fold the card in half, and draw the half heart and stem design.

tips: Note that extra creases are needed to create a pop-up.
The heart is made to stand away from the backing sheet, using a connecting stem which acts as a multi-piece Horizontal "V".
The complex structure is made from just one slit.
Note how the long creases down the edges of the card hold the card in a shallow "V"-shape, using the Horizontal "V" technique which enables the pop-up to keep its shape.

steps.instruction: Mark a line across the middle of the card, then add the horizontal lines so that the distances indicated are exactly equal, as shown.

projects.name: Design Eight

steps.instruction: Draw a line across the middle of the paper, then add three horizontal lines so that the distances indicated are exactly equal. Draw a basic heart shape.

steps.instruction: Using the original drawing as a guide, draw a "stepped" heart, taking care to ensure that the steps are symmetrical.

steps.instruction: Mark a series of vertical lines all the same length as the measurement indicated.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the stepped heart with vertical lines marked on the steps.

steps.instruction: Erase all excess lines, then cut and crease the pop-up, following the colour coding.
steps.visual_description: A diagram showing the final pop-up heart shape with red and green lines indicating cuts and creases.

tips: The design must be made with great accuracy if it is to look good, but the extra care will be well rewarded!

Use thick paper.

steps.visual_description: A sheet of paper folded in half with a heart shape drawn on it, showing cut lines.

steps.instruction: Unfold the paper. Crease across the bottom of the sheet to create the tabs. Follow the procedure described in the Horizontal "V" techniques (see page 70), to glue the tabs accurately to the backing sheet.

tips: Note that the angle of the "V" can change from being almost a straight line perpendicularly across the gutter crease, to being almost closed up along the gutter crease. In this example, the central area of the "Vs" has been cut out.

steps.instruction: Draw the design on a sheet of thick paper, then cut it out. Follow the procedures described in the Horizontal "V" techniques (see page 70), to glue the tabs accurately to the backing sheet.

tips: The effect is most attractive and an interesting alternative to the conventional Horizontal "V" design described in project nine.

tips: The wider the heart, the wider the support can be, and the better the mechanism will work.

projects.name: COMPUTER BROCHURE
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up brochure designed as a laptop computer, created as a project piece by a Graphic Design student. It explores how a pop-up can add visual impact to a conventional sales brochure. The structure uses the Floating Layers technique. Unusually, the gutter crease is located beneath the screen, and the left-hand half of the structure has been removed and replaced by a supporting prop (which is out of sight to the camera).

diagram_descriptions: A photograph of an open pop-up brochure designed to resemble a laptop computer. The laptop screen displays a graphic design software interface with a black and white image of a person. The keyboard and trackpad are detailed in a dark grey tone. The laptop is integrated into a larger brochure, which is open. To the right of the laptop, a page shows a 'technical specification' diagram with an illustration of a laptop and lines pointing to its various components. To the left of the laptop, another page of the brochure displays a colorful pattern resembling polka dots and some text. The number '20' is visible on the left side of the laptop screen. The overall height of the pop-up structure is 14 cm (5Â½ in).

steps.instruction: Cut out a heart and a support from a sheet of thick paper; note the glue tabs on the support.

steps.instruction: Glue the support to the backing sheet so that the distances indicated are measured and equal. Then glue the heart to one of the faces.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Glue support to backing sheet ensuring equal distances from top/bottom. Attach heart to one face of the support.

tips: The Scenery Flats technique is versatile, but if the supporting tabs are too long the heart will stand well away from the gutter crease, and fall even further away when the card is closed up. If this is the case, the card will have to be unnecessarily deep to accommodate the falling heart.

tips: The card is best appreciated while it is being opened and closed.

steps.instruction: Mark a line down the middle of the card, then add three vertical lines so that the distances A indicated are exactly equal.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The Generations technique (see page 55) is used. Ensure accurate positioning of the smaller heart on the larger. Cut foreground forms away from background forms.

steps.instruction: Draw the two hearts, noting how they fit together, and how they sit on the vertical lines. Erase all excess lines, then cut and crease, following the colour coding.

projects.name: Design Seven

steps.instruction: Follow the construction of design six (see step 1), then draw a horizontal line.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a rectangle divided by three vertical lines and one horizontal line.

steps.instruction: Add two hearts, noting that the position of the slits differs on each heart.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a rectangle divided by a vertical line, with two heart shapes drawn inside. Each heart has a slit, with the slits positioned differently on each heart.

steps.instruction: Erase all excess lines, then cut and crease the pop-up, following the colour coding. Interlock the hearts.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing a rectangle divided by a vertical line, with two heart shapes cut out and interlocked. The hearts are shown in profile, indicating a pop-up mechanism.

tips: The two hearts can be set at different levels and at different angles to each other to create any number of unusual compositions.
See also page 131 for a heart pierced by an arrow made using the same technique.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card with two interlocked hearts that twist through 90 degrees, connected to the backing sheet by creases along the side of the hearts.

projects.name: Design Eight

materials.item: sturdy card (cardboard) for the backing sheet

steps.instruction: Cut out the hearts, following the templates. Note how they intertwine at the centre and how a short vertical crease forms. Glue the shape to the backing sheet, following the procedure described in the Horizontal "V" techniques section (see page 70).
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing two heart shapes that are interlocked at the center and have a short vertical crease. The hearts are shown attached to a backing sheet.

steps.instruction: The wide base to each heart is necessary to "power" the heart upright when the card is opened. If they had narrow bases, the hearts would fall weakly inwards when the card was opened.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing two heart shapes with wide bases, indicating how they stand upright when the card is opened.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card where two hearts are made to stand up from a 180-degree (flat) backing sheet. The centres of the hearts were cut out.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up card with two interlocked hearts that twist through 90 degrees, connected to the backing sheet by creases along the side of the hearts. The card is decorated with oil pastels.
Diagram showing a rectangle divided by three vertical lines and one horizontal line.
Diagram showing a rectangle divided by a vertical line, with two heart shapes drawn inside. Each heart has a slit, with the slits positioned differently on each heart.
Diagram showing a rectangle divided by a vertical line, with two heart shapes cut out and interlocked. The hearts are shown in profile, indicating a pop-up mechanism.
A pop-up card with two interlocked hearts that stand up from a flat backing sheet. The centres of the hearts have been cut out.

projects.name: Design Nine

steps.instruction: Cut out two heart shapes, identical but for the slits, from thick paper.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing two heart shapes, one with a folded section and slits indicated by red lines.

steps.instruction: Crease the heart shapes, following the colour coding.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing two heart shapes, one with a folded section and slits indicated by red lines.

steps.instruction: Interlock the two slits.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing two heart shapes, one with a folded section and slits indicated by red lines.

steps.instruction: Glue the hearts to the backing sheet, following the procedure described in Horizontal "V" techniques (see page 70).
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing two heart shapes, one with a folded section and slits indicated by red lines.

tips: The two slits will lock the hearts together well, but they must be accurately cut.
If they need strengthening, add a piece of sticky tape.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring two interlocking heart shapes on a decorated backing sheet.

projects.name: Design Ten

steps.instruction: Cut out two heart shapes, following the templates.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing an upper heart template and a lower heart support template. The upper heart is a simple heart shape with a vertical crease line. The lower heart support is a rectangular shape with dotted and solid lines indicating folds and cuts.

steps.instruction: The creases can be in any position.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing an upper heart template and a lower heart support template. The upper heart is a simple heart shape with a vertical crease line. The lower heart support is a rectangular shape with dotted and solid lines indicating folds and cuts.

steps.instruction: Make six supports, three of one height and three of another.
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing an upper heart template and a lower heart support template. The upper heart is a simple heart shape with a vertical crease line. The lower heart support is a rectangular shape with dotted and solid lines indicating folds and cuts.

steps.instruction: Glue the supports to the backing sheet and the hearts to the supports, following the procedure described in the Floating Layers technique (see page 74).
steps.visual_description: Diagram showing an upper heart template and a lower heart support template. The upper heart is a simple heart shape with a vertical crease line. The lower heart support is a rectangular shape with dotted and solid lines indicating folds and cuts.

tips: The overlapping of one heart over the other creates an interesting layered effect.
It is not advisable to make the supports too high, as this begins to both distort the shape of the floating layer and make the structure look ungainly.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card with two floating heart layers, one overlapping the other.

templates.name: Upper Heart Template
templates.shape_description: A heart shape with a single vertical crease line down the center.

templates.name: Lower Heart Support Template
templates.shape_description: A rectangular strip with dotted lines indicating folds and solid lines indicating cuts. It has a textured pattern on one side.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing two heart shapes for Design Nine, one with a folded section and slits indicated by red lines.
Diagram showing an upper heart template for Design Ten, a simple heart shape with a vertical crease line.
Diagram showing a lower heart support template for Design Ten, a rectangular shape with dotted and solid lines indicating folds and cuts, and a textured pattern on one side.
Illustration of the finished pop-up card for Design Nine, featuring two red heart shapes interlocked and standing up from a gold patterned background.
Illustration of the finished pop-up card for Design Ten, showing two pink heart shapes layered and floating within a card base.

projects.name: Design Eleven

steps.instruction: Cut out two heart shapes, following the templates. Note that one has a glue tab and a horizontal slit at the bottom.
steps.visual_description: Two heart shapes are shown. One is a plain heart. The second heart has a small rectangular tab at the bottom and a horizontal slit cut into the tab.

steps.instruction: Make the horizontal support. Note that the slit and the measured distance are equal to that on the heart.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular strip is shown with a horizontal slit near the top and another near the bottom. A vertical line is marked in the center, and a bracket labeled 'A' indicates the distance between the two slits.

steps.instruction: Glue the support to the backing sheet so that the measured distances are equal.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular backing sheet is shown with a horizontal green line across it. A smaller rectangle, representing the support, is glued onto the backing sheet. This smaller rectangle has a horizontal red line and a horizontal green line, with a slit cut into it. The distance between the red and green lines is labeled 'A'. The support is positioned so that the red line aligns with the green line on the backing sheet, and the distance from the top edge of the support to the slit is also labeled 'A'.

steps.instruction: Interlock the heart with the slit. The two slits will slide together if the measurements have been made accurately.
steps.visual_description: A hand is shown holding a pop-up card base. A red heart with a slit in its tab is being inserted into a slit on a vertical support on the card base. Another red heart is already attached to the support.

steps.instruction: Glue the other heart to the front of the support.
steps.visual_description: A hand is shown holding a pop-up card base. A second red heart is being glued to the front of a vertical support on the card base. The first heart is already attached and interlocked.

tips: It is easy to make the mistake of cutting the slits in the heart and the support too long, so that when interlocked the rear heart slides too far to lie directly behind the front heart. Make the slits shorter than necessary, then elongate them if necessary.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring two red hearts that stand up from the card base.

templates.name: Heart template
templates.shape_description: A heart shape. One version has a glue tab at the bottom with a horizontal slit.

templates.name: Horizontal support template
templates.shape_description: A rectangular strip with a horizontal slit near the top and another near the bottom. A vertical line is marked in the center, and a bracket labeled 'A' indicates the distance between the two slits.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a plain heart shape.
Diagram showing a heart shape with a glue tab and a horizontal slit at the bottom.
Diagram of a rectangular support strip with two horizontal slits and a measurement indicator 'A'.
Diagram of a backing sheet with a horizontal line and a glued support strip, showing measurement 'A' and alignment.
Photograph of hands assembling a pop-up card, interlocking a heart with a slit into a support.
Photograph of hands gluing a second heart to the support of a pop-up card.

projects.name: SHEEP

steps.instruction: The Scenery Flats technique is used here. A rubber band is stretched diagonally from front to back to keep the structure in tension. Releasing the pressure allows the band to contract, so that the sheep automatically erects itself.
steps.visual_description: A 3D paper craft sheep with a fluffy body and black head and legs.

projects.finished_product_description: A 3D paper craft sheep that stands on its own.

diagram_descriptions: A 3D paper craft sheep with a fluffy body and black head and legs, standing on a light blue background.
A small icon of a heart shape with a leaf pattern inside.

projects.name: Design Twelve

tools.name: templates
tools.purpose: guiding cuts for hearts and supports

steps.instruction: Using the provided templates as a guide, make two identical support strips and two identical heart shapes.
steps.visual_description: Template outlines for a heart and a rectangular support strip with dotted ends and a central red line.

steps.instruction: Glue one support strip across the gutter (center fold) of the backing sheet, ensuring that the measured distances from the gutter to the ends of the support are equal. Glue down the second support strip, but rotate it 180 degrees relative to the first, so that its shorter face is on the opposite side of the gutter crease compared to the first support. Refer to figures 1 and 2 for placement.
steps.visual_description: Figure 1 shows one support strip (labeled A) glued horizontally across the center fold. Figure 2 shows two support strips (labeled A) glued horizontally across the center fold, with one rotated 180 degrees to mirror the other.

steps.instruction: Glue the two heart shapes to the shorter faces of the support strips in such a way that the entire pop-up structure will fold flat in half and allow the card to shut. Refer to figure 3.
steps.visual_description: Figure 3 shows the two support strips (with dotted ends) folded flat within the card base, indicating how the structure should collapse.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The two support strips are glued across the center fold of the backing sheet, with one rotated 180 degrees to create a mirrored effect. Hearts are then attached to the shorter faces of these supports to allow the card to fold flat.

tips: This project is a doubling of a previous project, creating an interesting effect.
The mirroring of the two supports creates hearts that are parallel to each half of the backing sheet.
Other supports can also be added to enhance the design.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring two red heart shapes that appear when the card is opened. The hearts are supported by a mirrored pop-up mechanism, creating a pleasingly complex yet simple structure.

templates.name: Heart Shape
templates.shape_description: An outline of a symmetrical heart shape, to be cut twice.

templates.name: Support Strip
templates.shape_description: A rectangular strip with two short sections at each end indicated by dotted lines (likely glue tabs), and a central section marked by a red line (likely a fold or measurement point). The main length is labeled 'A'. To be cut twice.

diagram_descriptions: Main image: A finished pop-up card, open to reveal two red heart shapes popping out from a beige card base. The hearts are positioned symmetrically, pointing outwards.
Photo 1: A pair of hands demonstrating the initial gluing of two vertical support strips onto a folded card base, showing the pop-up mechanism starting to form.
Photo 2: A pair of hands demonstrating the attachment of a red heart shape onto one of the pop-up support strips.
Figure 1: A diagram showing a single rectangular support strip (labeled 'A') positioned horizontally across the vertical center fold of a card base, indicating its initial placement.

Figure 2: A diagram showing two rectangular support strips (labeled 'A') positioned horizontally across the vertical center fold of a card base. One support is shown rotated 180 degrees relative to the other, illustrating the mirrored placement.
Figure 3: A diagram showing the two support strips (with dotted ends) folded flat within the card base, demonstrating how the pop-up mechanism should collapse when the card is closed.

projects.name: Design Thirteen

steps.instruction: Glue the larger support to the backing sheet by positioning it symmetrically across the gutter crease.
steps.visual_description: Hands gluing a folded paper support onto a backing sheet, with a crease in the middle.

steps.instruction: Glue the larger heart to one side of the support.
steps.visual_description: Hands gluing a red heart onto a folded paper support.

steps.instruction: Glue the second support symmetrically to the backing sheet and the heart, as in step 2.
steps.visual_description: Hands gluing a second folded paper support onto the backing sheet, aligning it with the first support and heart.

steps.instruction: Finally, glue the second heart to the smaller support.
steps.visual_description: Hands gluing a second red heart onto the smaller paper support.

tips: Scenery flats need not be glued to supports that lie square-on to the backing sheet; they can lie at other angles, eliminating the box-like effect of the previous project.
One support can provide the ground for a second generation, as shown here.
Use thick paper for the pop-ups and sturdy card (cardboard) for the backing sheet.
Using the template as a guide, make two supports. Note that one is smaller than the other.
Make two hearts, one a little smaller than the other.

The technique may continue to three or four generations of supports, each built on the previous one. By changing the angle of the "V" formed by each support, the flats can lie at different angles to each other.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring two red hearts attached to layered supports, creating a 3D effect.

templates.shape_description: A large heart shape.

templates.name: large heart support
templates.shape_description: A rectangular strip with markings indicating where to fold and glue. It has red and green dots at the ends and red lines in the middle.

templates.shape_description: A small heart shape.
