projects.name: Design Fourteen

steps.instruction: Glue the strap symmetrically to the backing sheet, ensuring the central mountain fold is aligned to the gutter crease.
steps.visual_description: Hands folding a red paper strip with creases.

steps.instruction: Then glue a heart to each end of the strap, following the procedure described in the Horizontal "V" techniques (see page 70). Two smaller hearts have been added for decoration.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a red paper strip with two pop-up hearts attached, with a small glue bottle visible.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Make two hearts and a strap. The heart shape is shown with a fold line down the center and cut lines at the bottom. The strap is shown with a central dashed fold line and two solid colored lines indicating other folds.

tips: An advantage of the Straps technique is to remove the pop-up form from the gutter crease, to create an unexpected empty centre to the construction.
The two hearts shown here are identical, but could be different.
Use thick paper for the pop-ups and sturdy card (cardboard) for the backing sheet.

The Straps technique can be used to even more dramatic effect if the mountain crease is off-centre, creating an asymmetrical strap. The result is two pop-ups placed asymmetrically either side of the gutter crease.
projects.finished_product_description: A red card with two pop-up hearts in the center, decorated with smaller white hearts. The pop-up mechanism creates an empty space in the center of the construction.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a rectangular strip with a dashed line down the center, and solid green and red lines on either side of the dashed line.
Diagram showing a heart shape with a solid red line down the center and dashed green lines at the bottom.
Illustration showing the heart shape with the bottom cut lines and the central fold line, labeled 'x 2'.
Photograph showing hands folding a red paper strip with creases.
Photograph showing hands gluing two pop-up red hearts to a red paper strip, with a small glue bottle visible.
Photograph of a finished red card with two pop-up red hearts and smaller white hearts decorating the card surface.

projects.name: Design Fifteen

steps.instruction: Glue the strap across the gutter crease, following the Straps technique shown on page 82.
steps.visual_description: A hand is shown folding a piece of paper with glue on it.

steps.instruction: Glue the hearts to the "V" crease, following the procedure described in the Horizontal "V" techniques section (see page 70).
steps.visual_description: A hand is shown attaching a red heart to a folded piece of paper.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Make the strap, being careful to note the equal angles. Then make the two hearts.

tips: Using the Asymmetric Angles technique, the "V" creases can be made to lie asymmetrically each side of the gutter crease. The result is a bizarre non-alignment of the pop-up on the "V"
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card with two red hearts emerging from a "V" shaped fold.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a curved strap with two fold lines and a dotted line at the bottom.
Diagram showing two heart shapes, each with a vertical fold line, and a dotted line at the bottom.
Illustration of a pop-up card with two red hearts standing upright.

projects.name: Design Sixteen

steps.instruction: Interlock the two hearts.
steps.visual_description: Hands interlocking two heart shapes, one red and one white, on a cutting mat.

steps.instruction: Glue the support to the back of the hearts, aligning the central crease on the support with the slits, ensuring that the bottom of the support is level with the bottom of the hearts. The form will push open to create a square.
steps.visual_description: Hands holding a white paper support and aligning it with the back of two interlocking heart shapes on a cutting mat. The support has a central crease and appears to be T-shaped.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Make two hearts, identical but for the placement of the slits, and a back support. Glue the support to the back of the hearts, aligning the central crease on the support with the slits, ensuring that the bottom of the support is level with the bottom of the hearts. The form will push open to create a square.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up design featuring two interlocking hearts with a support structure.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing two heart shapes, one above the other, with a vertical red line indicating a crease. Below is a T-shaped piece with a central red crease line and dotted green lines at the ends, indicating slits.
Illustration of a small square with a leaf-like icon inside, possibly a symbol for a technique or design element.

projects.name: PARALLO
projects.finished_product_description: A commercially available card that creates a dynamic abstract form. The clever use of black and white helps to exaggerate the complexity of the structure.

projects.name: DOUBLE HEARTS
projects.finished_product_description: Two hearts, one red and one white, interlocked to form a single unit. The back support may be replaced by two more hearts.

diagram_descriptions: A black and white abstract geometric sculpture made of folded paper or card, standing on a white surface.
Two interlocking heart shapes, one red and one white, casting a shadow on a light blue background.

projects.name: Hearts with Arrows

steps.instruction: Draw a line down the middle of the card, then add three vertical lines so that the measurements indicated are equal.
steps.visual_description: A rectangular card with a central vertical line and three additional vertical lines, creating four equal vertical segments. Horizontal lines indicate equal spacing between the vertical lines.

steps.instruction: Draw the heart and arrow. Erase all excess lines, then cut and crease the pop-up, as shown.
steps.visual_description: The rectangular card structure from step 1, now with a heart shape drawn in the center, pierced by a horizontal arrow with a zig-zag shaft. Excess lines are shown to be erased, indicating the final cut and crease lines for the pop-up.

details.details: Heart shape pierced by a zig-zag arrow, indicating cut and crease lines for the pop-up mechanism.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The zig-zag step in the shaft of the arrow must be minimized to reduce the stepping effect; if the creases it forms are too short, the construction may rip. The arrow need not be horizontal, but could be at an angle, perhaps pointing downwards, provided the creases remain vertical and parallel to the gutter to create a collapsible pop-up.

tips: Minimize the zig-zag step in the arrow shaft to reduce the stepping effect.
Ensure creases are not too short to prevent the construction from ripping.
The arrow can be positioned at an angle (not just horizontal) as long as the creases remain vertical and parallel to the gutter for a collapsible pop-up.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a heart pierced by an arrow, created using the 'Cut Away technique' to form 'negative' shapes like the arrowhead. The card can be decorated by rubbing pastels (broken to a powder) onto a marble-effect card.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a rectangular card with a central vertical line and three additional vertical lines, creating four equal vertical segments. Horizontal lines indicate equal spacing between the vertical lines.

Diagram showing the same card structure with a heart shape drawn in the center, pierced by a horizontal arrow with a zig-zag shaft. Excess lines are shown to be erased, indicating the cut and crease lines for the pop-up.
Photo of a small, partially open pop-up card with vertical stripes (light green and white). A red heart pierced by a black arrow is popping up from the center.

Photo of a larger, fully open pop-up card with a light brown, marble-effect texture. A large red heart with a black arrow piercing it is popping up from the center. The arrow is a cut-away, revealing a blue background.

projects.name: Design Two

steps.instruction: Mark a line down the middle of a piece of card, then add two equidistant lines.
steps.visual_description: A rectangle with three vertical lines, the center one thicker, and two thinner lines equidistant from it.

steps.instruction: Draw the heart and arrow. Note the slot, which is wide enough to take the arrowhead.
steps.visual_description: A rectangle with a heart shape on the left and an arrow shape on the right, separated by a vertical line. The heart has a small vertical slot. The arrow has a slot that appears to be for interlocking.

steps.instruction: Erase all excess lines, then cut and crease the pop-up. Interlock the arrow with the heart.
steps.visual_description: A pop-up heart with an arrow interlocked through it.

tips: The simplicity of the method has great appeal.
It may be applied to many other double subjects in which the two shapes are very different.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up heart with an arrow interlocked through it.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a rectangle with three vertical lines.
Diagram showing a heart shape and an arrow shape with slots, separated by a vertical line.
A photograph of a finished pop-up heart with an arrow interlocked through it, standing on a patterned surface.

projects.name: Design Three: Horizontal "V" Technique

steps.instruction: Glue the heart to one arm of the "V". The slit must lie over the crease on the middle of the "V".
steps.visual_description: A hand is shown holding a red, textured heart shape and placing it onto a blue patterned sheet. The heart is positioned on the left side of a folded 'V' shape, aligning a slit on the heart with the crease of the 'V'.

steps.instruction: Push the arrow through the slit and glue it to the arm of the "V" to which the heart is not glued.
steps.visual_description: A hand is shown pushing an arrow shape through the slit of the 'V' shape. The arrow is being glued to the right arm of the 'V'.

steps.instruction: Glue the flight onto the arrow.
steps.visual_description: A hand is shown holding a small, red, textured shape (presumably the 'flight') and gluing it to the end of the arrow.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Cut out the heart, support, arrow and flight. Glue the support to the backing sheet, following the procedure described in the Horizontal "V" techniques section (see page 70).

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a heart and an arrow, created using the Horizontal "V" technique.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a heart shape with a vertical slit in the center.
Diagram showing a trapezoidal shape with a dashed vertical fold line in the center, a solid horizontal slit near the bottom, and a dotted area at the bottom.
Diagram of an arrow shape.

Photograph showing a hand gluing a small red textured piece ('flight') onto the end of the arrow.

projects.name: Windsor Castle
tips: The "V"-shaped support is used here to create an "X"-shaped pop-up.
Note, particularly, how the arrow is attached to the "V": it is important to remember that a plane can be pierced to attach another plane to a support behind.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a castle and village scene, with a separate pop-up heart element.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up scene depicting Windsor Castle on a hill with trees and a village of houses in the foreground. The castle is grey with a flag and arched doorway. The houses are small and white with pitched roofs and colorful doors. The scene is viewed from a high viewpoint.

A pop-up heart element on a blue textured background. The heart is red and appears to be made of layered paper. A small black triangle is visible inside the heart, and a small red arrow-like shape is attached to the top right of the heart.

projects.name: Design Four

steps.instruction: Glue the two supports to the backing sheet, noting that the distance between the gutter and the right-hand support is the same as that between the crease on the heart and the slit. Glue the heart onto the supports, as described on page 74.
steps.visual_description: A pair of hands is shown gluing two white rectangular pop-up supports onto a light grey grid-patterned backing sheet. The supports are positioned to create a pop-up mechanism.

steps.instruction: Push the arrow through the slit.
steps.visual_description: A pair of hands is shown pushing a brown arrow-shaped piece through a vertical slit in the center of a white heart shape. The heart is resting on the previously glued supports on the backing sheet. A glue stick is visible in the background.

steps.instruction: Glue it to the heart directly beneath and to the backing sheet.
steps.visual_description: A pair of hands is shown pressing down the bottom part of the brown arrow onto the white heart and the backing sheet, securing it in place. The heart is now fully attached to the supports and the arrow is through it.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Cut out the heart, noting the slit. Make two supports as described in the Floating Layers technique (see page 74). Note distance B.

tips: To add a little variety, the heart need not be glued symmetrically to the supports. See the tenth Double Heart project for a reference (page 121).
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a white heart shape with a brown arrow piercing through its center, standing upright from a light grey backing sheet, creating a three-dimensional effect.

projects.name: Design Five

steps.instruction: Glue the heart, then the arrow, onto the backing sheet along the left-hand line.
steps.visual_description: Hands gluing a red heart and an arrow onto a striped backing sheet along a vertical line.

steps.instruction: Push the arrow through the slit and glue it along the right-hand line.
steps.visual_description: Hands pushing an arrow through a slit in a striped backing sheet and gluing it along a vertical line.

steps.instruction: Apply glue to the flight and lay it over the glued end of the arrow, flat against the backing sheet.
steps.visual_description: Hands applying glue to the fletching (flight) of an arrow and laying it flat against a striped backing sheet.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The backing sheet opens to 90 degrees. The arrow does not form a square as might be expected when the card is opened. The ability of the arrow to ride through the slit in the heart means that precise geometry is not necessary for the construction to collapse flat.

projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a red heart with an arrow passing through it, mounted on a striped backing sheet that opens to 90 degrees.

A small geometric shape representing the flight of the arrow is below the arrow. A rectangle with vertical and horizontal lines is shown to the right, with text indicating to mark a line down the middle and add two equidistant lines.
Photo showing a finished pop-up card with a red heart and an arrow, against a blue background.

projects.name: Design Six

materials.purpose: for pop-up and sturdy card (cardboard) for the backing sheet

steps.instruction: Glue the support to the backing sheet
steps.visual_description: A pop-up card base with a support structure being glued to it. A glue stick is visible.

steps.instruction: Glue the heart and arrow to the indented triangles as described in the Pivots section (see page 92).
steps.visual_description: A pop-up card base with the support structure visible. A hand is holding a red heart and an arrow, positioning them onto the indented triangles of the support.

steps.instruction: Finish off the design by gluing the cover over the support.
steps.visual_description: A pop-up card base with the heart and arrow attached. A hand is holding a rectangular piece of paper (the cover) to glue it over the support structure.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The support piece has cut lines that form triangles for attaching the heart and arrow. The cover is glued over the support.

tips: Though fun, this card must be put together with care. Perhaps the most reliable way to construct it would be to make a rough first, so that the final, neat version would be guaranteed to work.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a heart and an arrow that emerge when the card is opened, using the double Pivot technique.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing the shapes to be cut: a heart, an arrow, a support piece with fold and cut lines, and a cover piece.
Diagram of the support piece showing fold lines (solid), cut lines (red), and guide lines (green).
Photograph of a pop-up card in an open state, showing the heart and arrow elements.
Photograph of a pop-up card in a closed state, showing the heart and arrow elements inside.

projects.name: Design Seven

steps.instruction: Apply glue to the end tab on the support, then fix it to the back of the heart near to the left-hand edge. Ensure that the bottom corner of the heart and the bottom edges of the support "legs" are level.
steps.visual_description: Hands applying glue to a paper support piece and attaching it to the back of a paper heart shape. A glue stick is visible.

steps.instruction: Push the shaft of the arrow through the slot in the heart.
steps.visual_description: Hands pushing a blue paper arrow shaft through a slot in a red paper heart.

steps.instruction: To lock the shaft, glue on the arrowhead.
steps.visual_description: Hands gluing a red paper arrowhead onto the end of a blue paper arrow shaft that is protruding from a red paper heart.

details.position: over the center of the horseshoe

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The crease for the arrow lies directly over the centre of the horseshoe. The support stands on three points.

tips: The Trellis principle can be used in many ways to support a flat shape at the front. The piercing arrow seen here is not essential, but an effective bonus.
projects.finished_product_description: A 3D red heart with a blue arrow piercing through it, supported by a blue and white horseshoe-shaped stand.

diagram_descriptions: Diagram showing a heart shape with a dashed line across its width and a solid line indicating its height.

Diagram showing a horseshoe shape with an arrow extending from it. A solid line indicates a crease over the center of the horseshoe, and a slot is shown in the center of the horseshoe. The end of the arrow has a tab.
Photograph of the finished 3D heart with arrow and support.
A small icon showing a leaf shape within a square frame.

projects.name: Masks

steps.instruction: The silver aikido mask (right) uses the Cylinder technique.
steps.visual_description: A pop-up mask with a silver, cylindrical element resembling a face cage, attached to a backing sheet with text.

steps.instruction: The red and white African mask (below) is attached to the backing sheet on the left of the gutter crease, and slides to and fro on a strap embedded into the backing sheet, on the right.
steps.visual_description: A pop-up blue card with a red and white patterned circular mask attached. The mask is positioned on the left side of the card's gutter crease and appears to slide on a strap.

projects.finished_product_description: A series of pop-up masks, some integrating text, created using technically simple pop-up techniques. One mask is silver and uses a cylinder technique, while another is red and white with a sliding mechanism.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up mask with a silver, cylindrical element resembling a face cage, attached to a backing sheet with text.
A pop-up blue card with a red and white patterned circular mask attached. The mask is positioned on the left side of the card's gutter crease and appears to slide on a strap.

projects.name: JAPANESE COURTESANS
tips: The boxed floor is exercise III of the Diagonal Box technique, subdivided in the manner of the Trellis technique. The courtesans are folded using origami techniques.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring Japanese courtesans in a boxed floor structure.

projects.name: PARTHENON
tips: The Square-on Box technique is used to create the basic outline of the building. Note the added white card (cardboard) spanning the gutter crease and the false yellow floor, made using the Floating Layers technique. The careful use of coloured card and pattern give visual interest to an otherwise simple construction.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up model of the Parthenon using the Square-on Box technique, with added white card and a yellow floor created with the Floating Layers technique.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up card featuring a white, multi-tiered structure with delicate paper figures and branches with small brown flowers. The structure is set within a red border and on a white background with a watercolor wash.

A pop-up model of the Parthenon, constructed with brown and white cardstock. The model is placed on a black mat with a Greek key pattern border. The interior of the Parthenon model has a yellow and white checkered floor.

projects.name: STREET FURNITURE
tips: The constructions are technically simple, but they are given greater power by the vigorous rendering of the surface with thick acrylic paint, to create an unusual impasto effect that is rough to the touch.
projects.finished_product_description: These two constructions form part of a pop-up book, made by a student of Graphic Design, which illustrates a short city walk.

projects.name: RABBITS IN A HAT
tips: The use of brightly coloured papers to create the flowers, contrasts well with the monochrome pop-up.
projects.finished_product_description: The cylindrical box, with a separate brim, makes an excellent top hat, and the rabbits rise back-to-back from the gutter crease.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up book construction depicting street furniture, featuring a signpost with a blue arrow on a white background, made with thick acrylic paint creating a rough texture.
A pop-up book construction with a street sign element, showing a grey and orange box on a grey base, with a blue arrow sign.
A pop-up card featuring a grey top hat with black rabbit ears emerging from the top. The hat sits on a red square, which is on a black base decorated with yellow and pink paper flowers.

projects.name: CRAZY CREATURES
projects.finished_product_description: A spread from a book of "crazy" creatures. The book opens not like a concertina, but like a series of "L" shapes and can hang like a mobile to display all the creatures simultaneously. The creases are distributed equally along the gutter, top, outer and bottom edges.

projects.name: WONDER
tips: The cards are made to stand using the Horizontal "V" technique.
projects.finished_product_description: A student project to promote fashion designs and accessories, featuring pop-ups on many of its spreads. When the pop-up erects as the spread opens, a pressure sensitive musical box begins to play a tune, which continues for as long as the page is open!

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up book spread featuring colorful, abstract paper creatures with exaggerated features and limbs, suspended by string.
An open pop-up book with a spread depicting characters from Alice in Wonderland, including the Mad Hatter and playing cards, with pop-up elements.

projects.name: Sagrada Familia
tips: The two layers of spires are formed using the Generations technique, connected to each other and to the backing sheet by just one or two very small tabs.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card depicting the Sagrada Familia.

projects.name: Pompidou Centre
tips: Note also the escalator construction ascending diagonally up the building.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card depicting the Pompidou Centre, with the bottom of the building descending below the backing sheet to mimic entering from below street level.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up card featuring the spires of the Sagrada Familia, shown from the front with the card open.
A pop-up card depicting the Pompidou Centre, showing the lower levels and escalators, with the card open.

projects.name: CHRYSANTHEMUM

steps.instruction: Create an eight by eight grid of interlocking slats using the Trellis technique. No glue is used, except to hold the two slats to the backing sheet. Careful measuring and cutting will ensure that a grid of this complexity will collapse flat.
steps.visual_description: A pale yellow, layered, spherical paper craft object on a white surface.

tips: Only careful measuring and cutting will ensure that a grid of this complexity will collapse flat.
projects.finished_product_description: A dense, layered, spherical paper craft object resembling a chrysanthemum.

projects.name: SNOWFLAKE

steps.instruction: The two arms of the snowflake criss-cross through the front layer of the reflective card (cardboard) and are joined to the back layer. As the card opens, the arms separate. The reflective card apparently multiplies the number of arms, to create the illusion of a three-dimensional snowflake.
steps.visual_description: A three-dimensional snowflake pop-up card inside a clear box. The snowflake has multiple arms and appears to be made of layered paper.

projects.finished_product_description: A three-dimensional snowflake pop-up card.

projects.name: CHRISTMAS TREE

steps.instruction: This two-piece design, made out of die-cut card (cardboard) does not pop-up automatically, but needs pressing into a three-dimensional shape from flat. The structure is essentially a diagonal box, with the two halves intertwining up the trunk. Glue tabs (out of sight at the back) hold the pieces together.
steps.visual_description: A close-up view of a layered, three-dimensional Christmas tree pop-up structure, made from white cardstock, viewed from the side.

tips: Glue tabs (out of sight at the back) hold the pieces together.
projects.finished_product_description: A two-piece, three-dimensional Christmas tree pop-up card.

diagram_descriptions: A pale yellow, layered, spherical paper craft object on a white surface.
A three-dimensional snowflake pop-up card inside a clear box. The snowflake has multiple arms and appears to be made of layered paper.
A close-up view of a layered, three-dimensional Christmas tree pop-up structure, made from white cardstock, viewed from the side.

projects.name: Sydney Opera House
tips: This magnificent construction, made out of coloured cards (cardboard), uses the Floating Layers technique as its base, then an unusual variation on the Strap technique to collapse the two lines of roofs. The loose triangular tab at the left is attached to a thread that has to be pulled to open the small roof, at the top left.
projects.finished_product_description: A model of the Sydney Opera House.

projects.name: Gold Star
tips: Two strips of gold card (cardboard) are slotted together in a manner similar to variation II of the Trellis technique, then bent into a circle to create the star effect. A rubber band holds the construction in shape. When flattened, the band stretches. If the pressure on the flat card is released, the band contracts and the card springs dramatically into shape.
projects.finished_product_description: A star shape made from gold card that can be flattened and springs back into shape.

diagram_descriptions: A model of the Sydney Opera House constructed from white paper or card, shown from a slightly elevated angle, with a blue background behind it.
A gold star-shaped construction made from folded card, shown from a top-down perspective, with some of its points extended and others collapsed.

projects.name: HIDDEN JUNGLE

details.description: jungle scene with trees and animals
attach to the back of the zig-zag pop-up

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The zig-zag collapses and folds flat against the hard surfaces at the back of the photograph. These surfaces are book covers, which can close around the pop-up to create a conventional-looking, closed book.

tips: The zig-zag collapses and folds flat against the hard surfaces at the back of the photograph.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up book with a jungle scene inside, made from a continuous zig-zag of card. The pop-up can be closed to look like a conventional book.

projects.name: YA BOO SUCKS!

details.description: face with exaggerated features, tongue sticking out, eyes, and supports

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The construction is made almost entirely from one sheet of card (cardboard) - even the tongue is integral. The only additions are the eyes and the supports behind them, which use Scenery Flats technique.

tips: The only additions are the eyes and the supports behind them, which use Scenery Flats technique.
projects.finished_product_description: A highly illustrated construction of a face with exaggerated features, including a tongue sticking out, made from a single sheet of card.

diagram_descriptions: A green pop-up card with a jungle scene featuring trees and animals, shown in an open, expanded state.
A caricature of a face with wide, bulging eyes, a large red tongue sticking out, and hands held up to the sides of its head, with fingers splayed.

projects.name: Rabbit

steps.instruction: Cut and fold the rabbit from one piece of card using simple origami techniques.
steps.visual_description: A white pop-up rabbit with red eyes on a card.

tips: The rabbit is an appropriate subject for a magician's business card.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up rabbit made from a single piece of card, positioned astride the gutter crease of a card.

projects.name: ABC Letters

steps.instruction: Use the Steps technique to describe the outline of straight and curved letter forms.
steps.visual_description: Three dimensional white letters 'A', 'B', and 'C' with layered outlines.

tips: Successive generations can create extra layers in front of the original one.
projects.finished_product_description: Three dimensional pop-up letters 'A', 'B', and 'C' created using the Steps technique.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up white rabbit with red eyes on an open card, with a black insert.
Three dimensional white pop-up letters 'A', 'B', and 'C' on a white surface with a light blue background.

projects.name: HOUSE BY O.M. UNGERS
tips: The basic Diagonal Box technique creates the simple box shape of the house.
The separate roof, however, is created by an ingenious mechanism which swivels it into place and which is beautiful to watch as the card is opened.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up house with a separate, swiveling roof.

projects.name: SPREAD FROM "POP-UP JOURNEY"
tips: This story-book features pop-ups designed and made by eight-year-old school children.
There are several spreads, each containing a different pop-up design.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up spread from a children's storybook featuring a ship and landscape.

diagram_descriptions: A white pop-up house with a simple box shape and a separate roof that swivels into place.
An open pop-up book spread featuring a colorful drawing of a ship with sails, a body of water, and a green landscape with a smiling sun.

projects.name: Steam Engine

steps.instruction: Built on a floating layer of the word "train", this solid-looking construction uses Box techniques to create the engine itself. The octagonal front to the boiler is particularly ingenious, closing like the iris of a camera as the backing sheet is pulled open. It is constructed from coloured card (cardboard) and decorated with gouache.
steps.visual_description: A green and brown paper model of a steam engine on a track.

projects.finished_product_description: A paper model of a steam engine with an octagonal front that closes like an iris.

projects.name: Digger

steps.instruction: The body of the vehicle below the cab is a basic box with a rubber band stretched taut across a diagonal. When the box is pushed flat, the rubber band stretches further. Releasing the pressure on the collapsed box, allows the band to contract and erect the vehicle. In turn, this automatically erects the scoop and digger arms, fore and aft. By pulling the exhaust pipe on the bonnet, the bucket can be made to move, and by pulling the orange light on top of the cab, the digger can also be made to move!
steps.visual_description: A yellow and black paper model of a digger with a front loader and an excavator arm.

projects.finished_product_description: A paper model of a digger with a functional scoop and excavator arm, operated by rubber bands.

diagram_descriptions: A paper model of a steam engine on a track, with detailed description of its construction and features.
A paper model of a digger with a front loader and an excavator arm, with a detailed description of its construction and moving parts.

projects.name: HOUSE
tips: Designed as a promotional item, the house is a basic square-on box with simple additions. The design folds flat for mailing. When removed from its envelope, a powerful rubber band, which was stretched taut, begins to contract and automatically erects the house with great speed, and dramatic effect!
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up house that erects itself.

projects.name: DIGGER
tips: Stretched diagonally across the inside of the digger, a taut rubber band keeps the pop-up in shape. The construction can be pushed flat, further stretching the band. When the pressure is removed, the digger automatically pops into its three-dimensional shape!
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up digger that erects itself.

diagram_descriptions: A 3D paper model of a red-roofed house with a chimney, windows, and a small porch. The house is sitting on a checkered base.
A 3D paper model of an orange digger with a movable arm and bucket, and caterpillar tracks.

projects.name: Rapunzel
tips: The tower and its conical roof are made using the Box technique, but it has many sides instead of the more usual four or six.
The large, curved, blank sheets are designed to contain the text of the story.
Note how the top edges lift slightly for easy reading; this is achieved by an ingenious strap system, which lifts as the spread opens.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up book spread featuring a multi-sided tower with a conical roof, and a scene with a figure climbing a rope.

projects.name: Beam Engine
tips: The beam actually works!
The grey disk in the foreground can be rotated by placing a finger on the dark spot.
By a series of ingenious couplings, this drives the shaft connecting the disk to the right-hand gutter crease pop-up, which in turn rotates the white disk to operate the beam.
Each of the three pop-ups along the gutter uses the Square-on Box technique.
Pulling the tab on the perimeter of the backing sheet, causes the boilerman to stoke the fire.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up model of a beam engine with moving parts, including a rotating disk and a figure of a boilerman.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up book spread showing a tall, multi-sided tower with a red conical roof and a rope ladder. A small green tree is visible to the right of the tower. The tower is designed to hold text on its sides.

A pop-up model of a beam engine. It features white cardboard structures, including boxes and vertical supports, with a horizontal beam connecting two rotating disks. One disk is in the foreground and has a dark spot for rotation. A small figure of a boilerman is positioned near a fire element.

projects.name: STORK
tips: The use of bent wire to create the legs and feet gives this design a lightness that card (cardboard) could not achieve.
Although card is the natural medium for a pop-up, there is no technical reason why other materials, such as wire, cotton thread or acetate, could not also be used.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up stork made from card with bent wire legs.

projects.name: PIRATES

tools.name: Square-on Box technique
tools.purpose: achieving the shape of the rowing boat

tips: The decoration was applied using pastel on coloured papers.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up rowing boat with pirates, where the figures flip forwards and backwards by pulling and pushing a shaft.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up stork made from white and black card, with orange beak and bent wire legs, set against a pale pink background.

A pop-up scene of a rowing boat with two pirate figures inside, on blue water with ripples. A skull and crossbones flag flies from the back of the boat. There is a small, round, orange object floating in the water.

projects.name: Cape Jasmine
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up card featuring a Cape Jasmine flower. The flower has six petals that pop up and fold flat. The structure is a horizontal box with splayed panels, and the central structure is slotted together similarly to a tulip.

projects.name: Two Buddhas
tips: Note that, unusually, the only straight edges occur in the short horizontal creases. Also note that all the cut edges are curved.
projects.finished_product_description: Two commercially available pop-up cards, part of a larger series of Buddhas, made as one-piece pop-ups. They use intricate Generations and Cut Away techniques.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up Cape Jasmine flower on a light-colored card. The flower is light yellow and has six petals. The card is open, showing the pop-up mechanism.

Two pop-up Buddha figures on separate cards. The left figure is on a dark brown card and is seated on a lotus. The right figure is on a red card and is standing. Both figures are white and cut out from the cardstock.

projects.name: Cow

steps.instruction: Construct a simple pop-up cow using the upturned Horizontal "V" technique and the folded spine technique. Ensure the udder hangs from the crease along the spine. Decorate the card with marker pens.
steps.technique: upturned Horizontal "V" technique, folded spine technique
steps.visual_description: A white paper cow with black spots, small horns, and an udder, standing on a light yellow pop-up base.

projects.finished_product_description: A simple pop-up cow, 8 cm (3 in) high, made with an upturned Horizontal 'V' and folded spine technique, decorated with marker pens.

projects.name: Fantasy Bird

steps.instruction: Create a complex, symmetrical construction using a combination of Box and Floating Layers techniques. Position the construction off-centre, to one side at the end of a strap, rather than astride the gutter crease, to achieve a less symmetrical and less static appearance.
steps.visual_description: A complex, abstract light beige paper bird sculpture made of multiple folded and layered paper elements, sitting on an off-centre pop-up base.

projects.finished_product_description: A complex, symmetrical pop-up fantasy bird, 32 cm (12Â½ in) high, constructed using Box and Floating Layers techniques, with an off-centre placement.

projects.name: Cheeses

steps.instruction: Construct two solid pop-up cheese wedges using a combination of Box techniques and Horizontal "V" techniques, filling them in across the top. The design should appear unusually solid and asymmetric.
steps.visual_description: Two solid paper pop-up cheese wedges, one light brown and one darker brown, on a white base.

projects.finished_product_description: Two solid, asymmetric pop-up cheese wedges, 8 cm (3 in) high, made with Box and Horizontal 'V' techniques.

diagram_descriptions: Photo of a white paper pop-up cow with black spots, small horns, and an udder, standing on a light yellow pop-up base.
Photo of a complex, abstract light beige paper bird sculpture made of multiple folded and layered paper elements, sitting on an off-centre pop-up base.
Photo of two solid paper pop-up cheese wedges, one light brown and one darker brown, on a white base.

projects.name: Wasp and Bug
projects.finished_product_description: An exquisite construction that pops up using a technique similar to the Pivot technique. It features delicate cutting of strands of card, beautiful detailed painting of insects, and the use of acetate and wire to form the wasp's wings. This design was made in an unusually poetic manner.

projects.name: Skull
projects.finished_product_description: A three-piece design that makes use of the upturned Horizontal "V" technique, to create a convincing representation of a skull. By being thrust forward from the gutter crease, a sense of volume is created.

projects.name: Three Abstracts
projects.finished_product_description: Beautiful, intricate one-piece designs that are part of a long series of abstracts by the same designer. They make complex use of the Generations and Steps techniques, but also use light and shade in a positive way to achieve their dazzling and dramatic effects.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up construction of a skull, shown from the front, with intricate cut-outs for the eye sockets, nose, and teeth. The skull is white and appears to be made of cardstock.

Three abstract pop-up designs shown side-by-side. Each design features a series of folded and cut paper elements creating geometric patterns and a sense of depth. The designs are white and appear to be made of cardstock.

projects.name: Gorillas
tips: The shape of the slit is made more complex though, to create the shape of the banana.
projects.finished_product_description: An eccentric and humorous pop-up design featuring gorillas and a banana. The fruit itself is constructed using nothing more than the basic example from the Single Slit Angle of Crease technique.

projects.name: Meilleurs Voeux Pour 1992

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The card is constructed with a double layer at the back. The platform at the top of the steps slots into the back layer, locking the construction.

tips: Note how the card is a double layer at the back.
The platform at the top of the steps slots into the back layer, locking the construction.
projects.finished_product_description: A one-piece pop-up New Year card produced for a French company. It makes unusual use of the Steps technique, where the steps are not cut square but at a shallow angle to create an intriguing visual effect.

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up card featuring insects and leaves, with a wasp-like insect prominently displayed.
A pop-up card featuring two gorillas, one holding a banana.
A pop-up card showing a simple architectural structure with steps, signed 'Meilleurs Voeux pour 1992'.

projects.name: The Pop-Up Cookout Cookbook

tools.name: spray paint
tools.purpose: to create spontaneous effects in offset printing

steps.instruction: Using spray paint on paper printing plates, create spontaneous effects in offset printing.
steps.visual_description: The image shows a pop-up structure with a starry background, a picket fence, and figures dressed as chefs holding utensils. The text describes this as a pop-up frieze extended to a width of 150 cm (60 in).

tips: The quality of the decoration, in particular the cheeky use of the dishcloth fabric, gives interest to a simple pop-up technique.
projects.finished_product_description: A pop-up frieze designed for an exhibition with a barbecue theme. When fully opened, it extends to a width of 150 cm (60 in).

projects.name: Rhythmic Notes of Seven Folds

tools.name: spray paint
tools.purpose: to create spontaneous effects in offset printing

steps.instruction: Using spray paint on paper printing plates, create spontaneous effects in offset printing, which usually requires several intermediate steps before a final image can be created.
steps.visual_description: The image shows a folded paper structure with a zig-zag pattern and cut-out shapes. The paper has a textured, multi-colored appearance with shades of pink, red, and orange. The text describes this as a one-piece pop-up which, when the zig-zag pleats are unfolded, extends to a length of 150 cm (60 in).

tips: The result adds textural interest to a one-piece pop-up.
projects.finished_product_description: A one-piece pop-up structure with zig-zag pleats that extends to a length of 150 cm (60 in) when unfolded. It has a height of 22 cm (8Â½ in).

diagram_descriptions: A pop-up structure with a starry background, a picket fence, and figures dressed as chefs holding utensils. The text describes this as a pop-up frieze extended to a width of 150 cm (60 in).

A folded paper structure with a zig-zag pattern and cut-out shapes. The paper has a textured, multi-colored appearance with shades of pink, red, and orange. The text describes this as a one-piece pop-up which, when the zig-zag pleats are unfolded, extends to a length of 150 cm (60 in).
Diagram of a pop-up structure with a hat and a rabbit inside, with flowers on a black base.
Illustration of a man making a silly face, sticking his tongue out and pulling on his ears with his hands.
